analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill extensively reforms Medicaid home and community based services (HCBS) waivers and establishes a risk-based managed care program for aging and disabled populations receiving nursing facility and waiver services. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it directly affects seriously ill populations through Medicaid waiver eligibility, reimbursement, service coordination, and provider standards. The bill also creates infrastructure such as workgroups, ombudsman roles, and training programs that could support palliative care integration and workforce development.
analysis.summary: HB1474 establishes comprehensive reforms to Indiana's Medicaid home and community based services waivers and creates the Pathways for Aging Risk Based Managed Care Program. It sets reimbursement methodologies, provider contracting requirements, and claims review processes impacting nursing facilities and HCBS providers. The bill also mandates registration and training for personal services attendants, enhances oversight via ombudsman programs, and appropriates funds for workforce training. These changes indirectly impact palliative care by affecting access, payment, and quality of care for seriously ill, aged, and disabled Medicaid recipients statewide.
key_provisions: Establishes the Pathways for Aging Risk Based Managed Care Program with base reimbursement rates and provider contracting requirements for nursing facilities and HCBS providers.
Requires managed care organizations to report claim denials, pay interest on late clean claims, and participate in claims reviews and external audits.
Creates a framework for Medicaid home and community based services waivers including eligibility, provider certification, service coordination, and individualized service plans.

Mandates registration and background checks for personal services attendants providing self-directed in-home care, including contract requirements and prohibitions on certain relatives providing compensated care.
Establishes the direct support professional training program fund financed by fees on authorized service providers to support workforce development.

Creates and expands the statewide waiver bureau of disabilities services ombudsman with access to records and complaint processes for individuals with developmental disabilities receiving waiver services.
Requires annual reporting on state savings from HCBS waivers and limits on institutional care use, with savings potentially funding additional waiver slots.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it significantly impacts seriously ill and disabled populations who often require palliative care services. By reforming Medicaid waiver programs and managed care reimbursement, it affects access to home and community based services that can include palliative care supports. The workforce provisions for personal services attendants and direct support professionals enhance the quality and availability of in-home care, which is critical for palliative care delivery. The establishment of ombudsman roles and appeals processes strengthens patient rights and protections for vulnerable populations. Overall, the bill creates infrastructure and payment mechanisms that could facilitate integration and expansion of palliative care within Medicaid-funded community services across Indiana.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through Medicaid payment reforms, workforce development for personal care attendants, and quality standards for home and community based services. It enhances service coordination and individualized care planning, which are essential for effective palliative care delivery. The managed care program and claims review processes improve financial stability of providers serving seriously ill patients. The ombudsman provisions provide advocacy and complaint mechanisms benefiting patients with serious illness and disabilities. These systemic changes support improved access and quality of care for populations commonly served by palliative care teams.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general adult hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on Medicaid home and community based services, managed care, and workforce training relevant to seriously ill and disabled populations, making it relevant and not excluded.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill authorizes the office of the secretary to adopt rules under IC 4-22-2 to implement Medicaid waiver provisions, claims processing, personal services attendant registration, appeals processes, and provider certification standards.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1474
Title: FSSA matters.
Description: FSSA matters. Adds additional duties to a workgroup currently organized concerning the pathways for aging risk based managed care program (program). Requires the office of the secretary of family and social services (office of the secretary) to determine the base reimbursement rate structure, methodology, and reimbursement rates for provider payment by managed care organizations under the program. Allows the office of the secretary to perform claims reviews of claims under the program. Requires a managed care organization participating in the program to do the following: (1) Contract with nursing facilities if certain conditions are met under the same terms for a specified time frame. (2) Submit monthly reports for claims that had a denial rate of at least five percent in the previous month. (3) Pay minimum reimbursement rates to providers. (4) Pay interest on unpaid claims that are later determined to be clean claims. Sets forth the powers and duties of the office of the secretary concerning Medicaid home and community based services waivers. Requires a provider of services under a home and community based services waiver to follow any waiver requirements under federal law and developed by the office of the secretary. Establishes requirements for home and community based services waivers. Relocates provisions requiring reimbursement for assisted living services for individuals who are aged and disabled and receiving services under a Medicaid waiver. Specifies that: (1) these provisions apply to a home and community based services waiver that included assisted living services as an available services before July 1, 2025; (2) these provisions apply to an individual receiving services under a home and community based services waiver; and (3) reimbursement is required for certain services that are part of the individual's home and community based service plan. Relocates provisions establishing limitations concerning assisted living services provided in a home and community based services program. Relocates a provision requiring the office of the secretary to annually determine any state savings generated by home and community based services. Removes a provision allowing the division of aging to adopt rules concerning an appeals process for a housing with services establishment provider's determination that the provider is unable to meet the health needs of a resident and allows the office of the secretary to adopt rules concerning the appeals process. Requires an individual who provides attendant care services for compensation from Medicaid to register with the office of the secretary. Removes the requirement that the division of aging administer programs established under Medicaid waivers for in-home services for treatment of medical conditions. Provides that provisions of law concerning the statewide waiver ombudsman apply to an individual who has a disability and receives services administered by the bureau of disabilities services. (Current law specifies that these provisions apply to an individual who has a developmental disability and receives services under the federal home and community based services program.) Specifies that these provisions do not apply to an individual served by the long term care ombudsman program. Changes references from "statewide waiver ombudsman" to "statewide bureau of disabilities services ombudsman". Requires the unit of services for the deaf and hard of hearing and the division (rather than the unit and the board of interpreters) to adopt rules creating standings for interpreters. Removes provisions concerning the board of interpreters. Repeals a provision providing that licensed home health agencies and licensed personal services agencies are approved to provide certain services under a Medicaid waiver granted to the state under federal law that provides services for treatment of medical conditions. Repeals language concerning a long term care services eligibility screen for purposes of the Community and Home Options to Institutional Care for the Elderly and Disabled program (CHOICE). Authorizes the division of disability and rehabilitative services to charge an authorized service provider that employs a direct service professional an annual fee. Establishes the direct support professional training program fund and appropriates money in the fund.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: The bill establishes comprehensive certification and training standards for nurse aides, qualified medication aides, and home health aides, which are critical components of the healthcare workforce providing care to seriously ill patients, including those receiving palliative care. It also includes provisions for dementia training, home health aide services, and telehealth prescribing for opioid dependence, all of which indirectly impact the quality and accessibility of palliative care. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care or hospice, the workforce development, training, and regulatory infrastructure it creates are highly relevant to improving care delivery for seriously ill populations.
analysis.summary: SB0473 enacts extensive reforms to healthcare workforce certification and training, including establishing the Certified Health Care Professions Commission to oversee nurse aides, qualified medication aides, and home health aides. It mandates dementia-specific training for home health aides and expands telehealth prescribing for opioid treatment programs. These provisions indirectly support palliative care by enhancing the competency and regulation of frontline caregivers who serve seriously ill patients statewide, improving care quality and safety in home and facility settings.
key_provisions: Establishes the Certified Health Care Professions Commission to oversee certification and registration of nurse aides, qualified medication aides, and home health aides.
Requires dementia-specific training programs for home health aides caring for individuals with Alzheimer's disease or related cognitive disorders.
Mandates competency-based training and supervised practicum for qualified medication aides, including optional insulin administration training.
Allows telehealth prescribing of certain opioid agonist medications for opioid dependence treatment under specified conditions.
Sets standards for home modification services under managed care programs to support patients' home environments.
Requires reporting and investigation of abuse, neglect, and misconduct by certified aides, enhancing patient protections.
Permits substitution of simulation hours for clinical hours in nursing education programs to expand workforce training capacity.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: This bill indirectly impacts palliative care by strengthening the healthcare workforce that provides direct care to seriously ill patients in home health and long-term care settings. The establishment of certification standards and dementia training improves the quality of care for patients with cognitive impairments common in serious illness. Telehealth provisions facilitate access to opioid treatment, which is relevant to symptom management in palliative care. The regulatory framework and continuing education requirements enhance patient safety and care quality, benefiting palliative care recipients across Indiana's healthcare settings.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill does not explicitly mention palliative care but affects it through workforce development, quality standards for home health and nurse aides, dementia care training, and telehealth expansion for opioid dependence treatment. These system-level changes improve care delivery infrastructure for seriously ill patients, including those receiving palliative care, by ensuring better trained and regulated caregivers and expanded access to symptom management therapies.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general hospice care (only pediatric hospice is tracked and this bill does not mention hospice), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. Its focus on workforce certification, dementia training, and telehealth prescribing is consistent with inclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires the Indiana Department of Health and the Certified Health Care Professions Commission to adopt rules for certification, training standards, and supervision of nurse aides, qualified medication aides, and home health aides. It also mandates rulemaking for opioid treatment program standards and telehealth prescribing.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0473
Title: Various health care matters.
Description: Various health care matters. Specifies the process for a managed care organization to follow concerning home modification services. Requires a patient of an opioid treatment program (program) who has tested positive on a drug test to be given a random drug test monthly until the patient passes the test. (Current law requires the patient to be tested weekly.) Allows a program to close on Sundays and federal holidays. Prohibits the division of mental health and addiction from: (1) requiring a program's medical director to have admitting privileges at a hospital; and (2) establishing rules or guidelines concerning program admission and medication that are more stringent than federal regulations. Allows specified health care providers to perform the initial assessment, examination, and evaluation of a patient being admitted to a program. Allows the medical staff of an ambulatory outpatient surgical center to make recommendations on the granting of clinical privileges or the appointment or reappointment of an applicant to the governing board of the ambulatory outpatient surgical center for a period not to exceed 36 months. (Current law allows medical staff of hospitals to make recommendations.) Establishes the certified health care professions commission (commission). Sets forth the requirements for the: (1) certification of nurse aides and qualified medication aides; and (2) registration of home health aides. Specifies the duties of the Indiana department of health and the commission in regulating these professions. Relocates provisions concerning training for home health aides and requires the commission to approve the training. Sets forth requirements on facilities in employing nurse aides. Specifies the definition of "nurse aide" for purposes of an administrative rule. Makes changes to the release of medical information statute. Modifies the duties of the center for deaf and hard of hearing education. Adds provisions regarding "family navigators" and specifies the role of family navigators in the provisions of the bill regarding the center for deaf and hard of hearing education. Allows a prescriber to prescribe certain agonist opioids through telehealth services for the treatment or management of opioid dependence. (Current law allows only a partial agonist to be prescribed through telehealth.) Allows certain residential care administrators an exemption from taking continuing education during the initial licensing period. Allows for the provision of certain anesthesia in a physician's office or a podiatrist's office without the office being accredited. (Current law allows for this in dental offices.) Requires adverse events concerning anesthesia in an office based setting to be reported to the medical licensing board of Indiana (board). Requires the board to: (1) determine the types of adverse events to be reported; (2) establish a procedure for reporting; and (3) post the adverse events on the board's website. Creates a process for certain individuals who do not have a Social Security number and who are seeking licensure by examination as a registered nurse or practical nurse to obtain a provisional license. Requires a nursing program to offer a clinical experience for clinical hours in a hospital and a health facility setting.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes a state income tax credit for family caregivers who provide unpaid care to ill or aging family members, excluding services requiring licensed medical professionals. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it directly supports informal caregiving for seriously ill individuals, a core component of palliative care support. By financially recognizing family caregivers, the bill indirectly impacts the care and quality of life of seriously ill patients and their families, which aligns with palliative care goals.
analysis.summary: SB0339 creates a caregiver tax credit allowing qualified taxpayers to claim a credit up to $10,000 for unpaid caregiving services provided to ill or aging family members. It excludes professional medical services but recognizes the value of informal caregiving, which is critical for seriously ill patients often receiving palliative care. This financial incentive may improve caregiver support statewide, potentially enhancing home-based care and reducing caregiver burden. The bill requires the Family and Social Services Administration to develop criteria and valuation methods for qualifying services.
key_provisions: Establishes a state income tax credit up to $10,000 for qualified taxpayers providing unpaid care to ill or aging family members.
Defines 'qualified services' as non-professional caregiving tasks determined by the Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA).
Requires FSSA to develop criteria and a valuation formula for qualified caregiving services using published industry data.
Mandates qualified taxpayers to submit caregiving information annually to FSSA for credit determination.
Excludes services requiring licensed medical professionals from qualifying for the credit.
Limits the credit to the taxpayer's state income tax liability with no carryover or refund provisions.
Applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2025, with FSSA guidelines due before January 1, 2026.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly supports palliative care by providing financial recognition and relief to family caregivers who deliver essential non-medical care to seriously ill and aging patients. This support can improve caregiver capacity and reduce burnout, enhancing the quality of home-based and community care environments where palliative care is often delivered. By valuing informal caregiving, the bill may encourage more family involvement in care plans, aligning with palliative care's holistic approach. The requirement for FSSA to develop service criteria and valuation creates infrastructure that could incorporate palliative care considerations.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it impacts the healthcare system by incentivizing unpaid caregiving, a critical component of care for seriously ill patients. It affects the caregiving workforce broadly, including those supporting patients receiving palliative care. The payment mechanism via tax credits influences financing for home and community-based care, indirectly affecting access and quality of palliative services. The bill also establishes administrative processes that could integrate palliative care service definitions in the future.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, hospice care (general or pediatric), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It centers on caregiver financial support, which is relevant to palliative care policy and does not fall under any exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: Requires the Family and Social Services Administration to develop criteria, valuation formulas, and guidelines to implement the caregiver tax credit, representing new regulatory responsibilities.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0339
Title: Caregiver tax credit.
Description: Caregiver tax credit. Provides that a qualified taxpayer is entitled to a credit against the qualified taxpayer's state income tax liability in a taxable year equal to the lesser of: (1) the value of qualified services that the qualified taxpayer performed in the immediately preceding taxable year; or (2) $10,000 (or $5,000 in the case of a married individual filing a separate return). Provides that "qualified services" means services, as determined by the office of the secretary of family and social services (FSSA), that a qualified taxpayer performs in caring for an ill or aging qualified family member that the qualified taxpayer otherwise would have compensated a third-party caregiver to perform. Provides that the term does not include services that would otherwise be required to be performed by a licensed physician, a licensed nurse, or other medical professional. Requires the FSSA to: (1) develop criteria that a service must satisfy to be considered a qualified service; (2) derive a formula, using published industry data and standards, to determine the value of the qualified services performed by a qualified taxpayer during a taxable year; and (3) adopt any other guidelines necessary to allow or disallow a credit. Requires a qualified taxpayer to submit to the FSSA all relevant information regarding the performance of qualified services necessary for the FSSA to determine the value of the qualified services. Requires the FSSA to notify a qualified taxpayer in writing the value of the services that the qualified taxpayer performed for purposes of claiming the credit.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill addresses healthcare provisions related to treatment and care decisions for minors and born alive infants, including requirements for hospitals to inform patients about capabilities and treatment options, and strict consent requirements for withholding or withdrawing life-sustaining treatment for minors. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it directly impacts care decisions for seriously ill infants and minors, including end-of-life treatment decisions, which are core concerns of pediatric palliative care. The bill also establishes legal and clinical standards that affect how life-sustaining treatments are managed, creating important implications for palliative care providers and families.
analysis.summary: HB1336 mandates hospitals to inform women in premature labor about treatment capabilities for born alive infants and high-risk pregnancies, requires consent from all parents or guardians before issuing do not resuscitate orders or withholding life-sustaining treatment for minors, and prohibits courts from withdrawing life-sustaining treatment over parental objections. These provisions directly affect pediatric patients with serious illness and the clinical and legal framework surrounding end-of-life care decisions. The bill's statewide application impacts hospitals, healthcare providers, and families involved in high-risk perinatal and pediatric care.
key_provisions: Hospitals must inform women in premature labor about their capabilities to treat born alive infants and manage high-risk pregnancies before admission.
Hospitals must offer transport options to a hospital with appropriate perinatal level of care for both born alive infants and their mothers.
Health care providers must obtain consent from each parent or legal guardian before issuing do not resuscitate orders or withholding/withdrawing life-sustaining treatment for minors.
Health care providers are prohibited from interfering with parental requests to transfer minor patients or from withholding life-saving measures during transfer.
Courts are prohibited from withdrawing life-sustaining treatment from minors over parental objections.
Local prosecuting attorneys must investigate health care providers suspected of knowingly violating care standards resulting in harm or death to born alive infants or mothers.
Hospitals must provide medical screening and stabilizing treatment to born alive infants and women in premature labor.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly impacts pediatric palliative care by regulating critical aspects of care decision-making for seriously ill infants and minors, particularly regarding life-sustaining treatments and parental consent. It reinforces protections for continuation of life, which may affect timing and delivery of palliative care services. Hospitals and providers must navigate these legal requirements while delivering symptom management and supportive care to this vulnerable population. The provisions create a legal framework that shapes clinical practice and family engagement in pediatric serious illness care, potentially limiting withdrawal of care without full parental agreement, thus influencing palliative care planning and delivery.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it affects healthcare delivery and decision-making for seriously ill pediatric patients and newborns, populations commonly served by palliative care teams. The requirements for hospital capability disclosures, consent processes, and transfer protocols influence care coordination and quality standards relevant to palliative care integration. Bill Number: HB1336
Title: Health care matters.
Description: Health care matters. Requires a hospital to inform a woman in premature labor of the hospital's capabilities of treating the born alive infant and managing a high risk pregnancy and, if the hospital's capabilities interfere with the woman's care, the hospital must provide this information before the woman is admitted to the hospital. Provides that if a born alive infant is transported to a hospital with an appropriate perinatal level of care, the woman must be offered an opportunity to be transported to the same hospital. Provides that if the local prosecuting attorney has probable cause to believe that a health care provider may have knowingly or intentionally: (1) violated the requirements concerning the treatment and care of a born alive infant or mother or the professional standards of practice through the health care provider's actions or inactions; and (2) caused harm or death to the born alive infant or mother; the prosecuting attorney shall investigate the health care provider for appropriate criminal prosecution. Establishes a presumption that the continuation of life is in a minor's best interests. Requires a health care provider to obtain the consent of each parent or each legal guardian before issuing a do not resuscitate order or otherwise withholding or withdrawing treatment to allow the natural death of a minor. Prohibits a health care provider from interfering with the transfer of a minor patient at the request of a parent or guardian or otherwise preventing life saving measures before or during the transfer. States that a court does not have jurisdiction to withdraw life sustaining treatment for a minor.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes and reforms Medicaid home and community based services (HCBS) for aged and disabled populations, including functional eligibility assessments and reimbursement policies. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it impacts populations commonly served by palliative care and affects Medicaid waiver programs that cover assisted living and home-based services. The bill also mandates clinical and quality of life measures and includes provisions for managed care programs that could integrate palliative care services.
analysis.summary: HB1592 reforms Medicaid aged and disabled waiver services by requiring timely functional eligibility assessments, prohibiting wait lists when waiver slots are available, and mandating reimbursement from application date. It establishes a new Medicaid waiver for assisted living services and creates a risk based managed care program with quality and clinical measures. These changes indirectly support seriously ill patients by improving access to home and community based services and care coordination, which are critical for palliative care integration statewide.
key_provisions: Requires Medicaid functional eligibility assessments and determinations to be completed timely and reimbursed if provider completes approved training
Prohibits Medicaid waiver wait lists if slots are available and mandates applying for additional waiver slots to avoid wait lists
Establishes a new Medicaid waiver specifically for assisted living services separate from aged and disabled waiver
Creates a risk based managed care program for aged and disabled Medicaid recipients including clinical and quality of life measures
Mandates provider credentialing, appeals processes, prompt payment requirements, and administrative oversight for managed care entities
Requires continuity of care protections and network adequacy standards for covered populations
Allows provider owned entities to participate in the managed care program and requires monthly reporting and audits of claim denials
analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly impacts palliative care by improving access and reimbursement for home and community based services that serve seriously ill aged and disabled populations. It enhances care coordination through risk based managed care programs and mandates clinical and quality of life measures that could include palliative care outcomes. Providers, including those delivering palliative care, benefit from improved claims processing, credentialing, and appeals protections. The statewide scope and inclusion of assisted living Medicaid waivers create infrastructure to integrate palliative care into long term services and supports.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: This bill affects Medicaid payment and eligibility processes, managed care program structures, and quality standards that influence care delivery for seriously ill patients without explicitly mentioning palliative care. It supports workforce training for functional assessments and care management, which could include palliative care professionals. The focus on home and community based services and assisted living settings aligns with environments where palliative care is often provided, thus indirectly benefiting palliative care access and quality.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general hospice care (other than Medicaid waivers for assisted living), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. Pediatric hospice is not mentioned. Therefore, it does not fall under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires the office of the secretary to develop and implement clinical and quality of life measures, adopt rules concerning appeals and provider determinations, and comply with federal Medicaid waiver regulations.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1592
Title: Services for the aged and disabled.
Description: Services for the aged and disabled. Allows the office of the secretary of family and social services (office) to reimburse a Medicaid provider for providing functional assessments if the provider completed training approved by the office. Prohibits the office from restricting access to certain assisted living services by establishing a Medicaid waiver wait list or any other method if there are available waiver slots. Requires the office to apply for additional waiver slots when the slots are all filled in a manner that is sufficient to complete the state fiscal year without implementing a wait list. Requires the office to reimburse for home and community based services from the date of the individual's application. Requires the office to apply to the federal government for: (1) an amendment to the aged and disabled Medicaid waiver concerning functional eligibility determinations and reimbursement within a specified time; and (2) a new Medicaid waiver to provide assisted living services. Repeals language concerning reporting of the development of a long term care risk based managed care program (program). Requires the office to include certain provisions in a contract for the program. Specifies requirements of an entity contracting with the office to participate in the program. Requires the office to develop and implement clinical and quality of life measures and allow provider owned entities to participate in the program. Allows the office to audit claims or data concerning the program and post the audit findings on the office's website. Allows the office to take administrative action against a contracted entity for violations. Sets forth claim submission and processing requirements for the program. Repeals the temporary emergency financial assistance program.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill addresses Medicaid home and community based waiver services for individuals with disabilities, including those with medically complex conditions who may benefit from palliative care. It establishes reporting requirements and advisory council involvement to ensure high quality services, which indirectly impacts care coordination and service delivery for seriously ill patients. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, its focus on individuals requiring extraordinary care and Medicaid waiver services aligns with populations served by palliative care programs.
analysis.summary: HB1689 revises provisions related to the statewide bureau of disabilities services ombudsman and mandates annual reporting on Medicaid home and community based waiver services for recipients with medically complex conditions. It requires advisory council recommendations to improve service quality and plans for individuals needing extraordinary care. These provisions indirectly support palliative care by enhancing oversight, coordination, and quality of care for seriously ill and disabled populations statewide.
key_provisions: Establishes the statewide bureau of disabilities services ombudsman with expanded authority and access to records for individuals with disabilities receiving waiver services.

Requires the office of the secretary of family and social services to prepare annual reports on Medicaid home and community based waiver services for recipients with medically complex conditions, categorized by age and county.
Mandates the division of disability and rehabilitative services advisory council to provide recommendations on ensuring high quality services, including evaluation of complex care assistant models.

Requires the office to present plans and proposed Medicaid waiver amendments related to services for individuals requiring extraordinary care to the advisory council for feedback before federal submission.
Provides immunity protections for providers releasing records to the ombudsman and establishes complaint intake and coordination mechanisms.
Includes provisions for structured family caregiving service arrangements and reimbursement for legally responsible individuals under Medicaid waivers.
Requires dissemination of reports to multiple state oversight and advisory bodies to inform policy and budgeting decisions.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly benefits palliative care by improving oversight, coordination, and quality of Medicaid home and community based services for individuals with serious and complex health needs who often require palliative care supports. It enhances protections and advocacy through the ombudsman program, supports data-driven policy via mandated reporting, and involves advisory councils in shaping care models including those for extraordinary care. These mechanisms can facilitate integration of palliative care principles into disability and complex care services, benefiting patients, families, providers, and payers across Indiana's community settings.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it impacts populations commonly served by palliative care through Medicaid waiver services for medically complex and disabled individuals. The establishment of reporting requirements, advisory council recommendations, and ombudsman oversight creates infrastructure that supports quality improvement and care coordination for seriously ill patients. Payment and reimbursement considerations for extraordinary care and family caregiving also affect service delivery relevant to palliative care.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It centers on disability services and Medicaid waivers, which are relevant to palliative care populations and service delivery without falling under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill references existing regulations governing Medicaid waiver services and requires the office of the secretary to submit waiver amendments to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, implying regulatory compliance and oversight.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1689
Title: Human services matters.
Description: Human services matters. Provides that provisions of law concerning the statewide waiver ombudsman apply to an individual who has a disability and receives services administered by the bureau of disabilities services. (Current law specifies that these provisions apply to an individual who has a developmental disability and receives services under the federal home and community based services program.) Specifies that these provisions do not apply to an individual served by the long term care ombudsman program. Changes references from "statewide waiver ombudsman" to "statewide bureau of disabilities services ombudsman". Requires the office of the secretary of family and social services (office of the secretary) to prepare an annual report on the provision of Medicaid home and community based waiver services. Specifies the information that must be included in the report. Requires the division of disability and rehabilitative services advisory council to provide recommendations to the division of disability and rehabilitative services to ensure the delivery of appropriate high quality services to recipients. Requires the office of the secretary to provide to the division of disability and rehabilitative services advisory council reports on the office of the secretary's plans to provide services to individuals who require extraordinary care and specifies the timing of the reports.

It includes provisions for tax credits and funding mechanisms that may enhance resources available for care of seriously ill patients, including those requiring symptom management and supportive services. Although it does not explicitly mention palliative care, the focus on long term care services and functional impairments aligns with populations who often benefit from palliative care integration.
analysis.summary: HB1588 creates a primary care access revolving fund to provide loans to primary care practices and establishes long term care savings accounts with favorable tax treatment to help employees and their dependents pay for long term care services. The bill expands tax credits for physician practice ownership and health reimbursement arrangements, aiming to increase access to primary care and long term care for individuals with chronic functional impairments. While not explicitly about palliative care, these provisions indirectly support seriously ill patients by enhancing care infrastructure and financing mechanisms statewide.
key_provisions: Establishes the Primary Care Access Revolving Fund to provide loans to primary care medical practices for facility improvements, equipment, and working capital.

analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly supports palliative care by enhancing financial mechanisms and infrastructure for primary care and long term care services, which serve many seriously ill patients who may benefit from palliative care. The long term care savings accounts help employees and their dependents manage costs related to chronic impairments, including services such as nursing, therapy, and respite care that overlap with palliative care needs. These provisions potentially improve access, affordability, and continuity of supportive care in community and home settings across Indiana.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through healthcare financing reforms and workforce support that do not explicitly mention palliative care but affect care delivery for seriously ill populations. The loan fund for primary care practices targets medically underserved and rural areas, potentially expanding access to providers who deliver palliative care services. The long term care savings accounts cover a broad range of supportive services critical to patients with chronic conditions, aligning with palliative care goals of symptom relief and quality of life improvement.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It centers on long term care financing and primary care access, which are relevant to palliative care policy without falling under excluded categories.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill authorizes the insurance commissioner and the department of state revenue to adopt rules necessary to implement the long term care savings account program.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1588
Title: Long term care savings accounts.
Description: Long term care savings accounts. Establishes the primary care access revolving fund (fund) for the purpose of making loans to primary care medical practices in Indiana. Specifies the purposes for which money in the fund may be loaned. Provides that the Indiana finance authority shall administer the fund. Requires the Indiana economic development corporation (IEDC) to transfer $15,000,000 to the fund from the amount appropriated to the IEDC by the general assembly in the 2025-2026 state fiscal year. Increases the employee threshold for purposes of eligibility for the health reimbursement arrangement income tax credit. Increases the maximum amount of tax credits that may be granted in a year. Specifies the procedure for claiming the credit. Allows an employer to establish a long term care savings account program that allows an employee to save with favorable tax treatment for services required when the employee's or the employee's dependents' functional capacities become chronically impaired due to advanced age or other circumstances. Expands the physician practice ownership tax credit (tax credit) against state tax liability to practicing physicians (instead of only primary care physicians) who have an ownership interest in a physician practice and meet other eligibility criteria. Requires a taxpayer claiming the tax credit to certify that each physician with an ownership interest provides health care services to patients. Provides that the total amount of tax credits awarded in a state fiscal year may not exceed $20,000,000.
Status: 1
Status Date: 2025-01-21
Sponsors: Bradford Barrett

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes a comprehensive state directed payment program for hospitals, modifies Medicaid disproportionate share hospital payments, and mandates financial reporting and pricing studies for nonprofit hospital systems. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it significantly impacts hospital payment structures, Medicaid funding, and hospital financial transparency, which indirectly affect access to and quality of care for seriously ill patients who often receive palliative care in hospital settings. The bill also includes provisions for managed care assessment fees and direct to employer health care arrangements that could influence reimbursement models relevant to palliative care services.
analysis.summary: HB1004 establishes a state directed payment program for hospitals, modifies Medicaid disproportionate share payment methodologies, and requires nonprofit hospital systems to submit detailed financial reports. It mandates a statewide study of hospital pricing and sets pricing benchmarks for nonprofit hospital systems, with penalties for noncompliance. These financial and payment reforms indirectly impact palliative care by influencing hospital funding and reimbursement, potentially affecting access and quality of care for seriously ill patients. The bill also includes managed care assessment fees and direct to employer health care arrangements, which may alter payment flows relevant to palliative care providers statewide.
tags: direct to employer health care arrangements
key_provisions: Establishes a state directed payment program for inpatient and outpatient hospital services with reimbursement rates potentially above Medicare equivalent rates, subject to federal approval.
Modifies Medicaid disproportionate share hospital payment methodologies and allows funding through hospital fees and managed care assessment fees.
Requires nonprofit hospital systems to submit audited financial statements annually with penalties for failure to comply.
Mandates a statewide study of commercial inpatient and outpatient hospital prices with a report due to the governor and legislature.

Sets a requirement that Indiana nonprofit hospital systems' average hospital prices must be at or below the statewide average by June 30, 2029, with loss of nonprofit status as penalty for noncompliance.
Requires disclosure of commissions and fees by insurers and third party administrators to policyholders and plan sponsors.
Establishes direct to employer health care arrangements with pricing benchmarks and audit requirements starting in 2025.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly address palliative care, its extensive reforms to hospital payment systems, Medicaid funding, and hospital financial transparency indirectly affect the delivery of palliative care services. By altering reimbursement rates and funding mechanisms for hospitals, including nonprofit systems that provide a substantial portion of care to seriously ill patients, the bill influences hospital capacity to offer comprehensive care including palliative services. The mandated pricing study and nonprofit hospital pricing caps may encourage cost containment and potentially impact resource allocation for specialty services. The managed care assessment fee and direct to employer arrangements also reshape payment flows that could affect palliative care providers. Overall, the bill creates infrastructure and financial conditions that could be leveraged to improve access, quality, and sustainability of palliative care within hospital settings statewide.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: This bill impacts palliative care through changes in Medicaid reimbursement and hospital payment programs that affect funding for inpatient and outpatient services where palliative care is delivered. The financial reporting requirements and pricing study promote transparency and accountability in hospital pricing, which can influence affordability and access for seriously ill patients. Managed care assessment fees and direct to employer health care arrangements introduce new payment models that may affect how palliative care services are reimbursed. These systemic healthcare financing and quality oversight changes provide opportunities to integrate and support palliative care without explicitly naming it.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general hospice care (adult), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on hospital payment reform, Medicaid funding, and financial transparency, which are relevant to palliative care policy indirectly.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires amendments to Medicaid state plans and waivers, subject to approval by the United States Department of Health and Human Services, including compliance with 42 CFR 438.6(c) for state directed payment programs. It also mandates updates to administrative rules and includes provisions for federal regulatory oversight of hospital fees and Medicaid payments.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1004
Title: Health care matters.
Description: Health care matters. Establishes: (1) a state directed payment program (program) for hospitals; and (2) a managed care assessment fee. Changes disproportionate share payments when a state directed payment program is in effect. Allows the incremental hospital fee fund to be used to fund the Medicaid program. Requires a nonprofit hospital system to submit audited financial statements. Provides for a $10,000 per day penalty for failure to submit the hospital's financial statements. Requires the office of management and budget (office) to: (1) develop a methodology to be used in conducting a study of commercial inpatient hospital prices and outpatient hospital prices; and (2) upon budget committee review, conduct the study to determine Indiana's statewide average inpatient and outpatient hospital prices. Requires the office to submit a report of the study to the governor and general assembly. Before June 30, 2029, requires an Indiana nonprofit hospital system's aggregate average inpatient and outpatient hospital prices to at least be equal to or less than the statewide average. States that a violation by the Indiana nonprofit hospital system results in a forfeiture of its nonprofit status. Requires, before October 1 of each year, every nonprofit hospital to provide the Indiana department of health with specified federally filed forms and specified data used to complete the forms. Requires the Indiana department of health to submit these forms to the health care cost oversight task force and impose a fine of $10,000 per day on a nonprofit hospital for failure to submit the nonprofit hospital's forms. Provides an exemption from health care billing requirements for a facility located in a specified populated municipality. Requires a third party administrator to disclose commissions and fees to policyholders in a separate notification. Requires an insurer and a health maintenance organization to submit specified data information to the all payer claims data base. Requires an insurance producer or third party administrator to, before or at the time of sale, provide the plan sponsor with a statement from the insurer or health maintenance organization, disclosing commissions and fees that the insurance producer or third party administrator will receive. Changes the time frame in which certain information and claims data must be submitted to a contract holder as part of an audit or claims data request. Sets requirements for certain hospitals concerning a direct to employer health care arrangement. Beginning January 1, 2026, requires a state employee health plan, a policy of accident and sickness insurance, and a health maintenance organization contract to provide a plan sponsor with the national average drug acquisition cost of a generic drug. States that if an agreement between a health plan and a pharmacy benefit manager provides that less than 85% of the estimated rebates will be deducted from the cost of prescription drugs before a covered individual's cost sharing requirement is determined, the pharmacy benefit manager must provide the policyholder with an annual notice that includes: (1) an explanation of what a rebate is; (2) an explanation of how rebates accrue to the health plan from the manufacturer; and (3) the aggregate amount of rebates that accrued to the health plan for prescription drugs dispensed under the policyholder's health plan for the previous year. Places limitations on hospital health provider contracts linking to or negotiating reimbursement or terms under a separate hospital health care provider contract or product. Requires the office to: (1) study the effect, including the fiscal impact, of requiring physician reimbursement rates under a commercial policy to be set at a minimum reimbursement rate; and (2) report its findings under the study. Requires certain health carriers to provide claims data to a contract holder not more than four times per year (current law allows for the provision of the data twice annually). Requires certain insurers and health maintenance organizations to file specified information concerning changes in hospital reimbursement to the department of insurance.

SECTION 2, IS AMENDED TO READ AS FOLLOWS [EFFECTIVE
UPON PASSAGE]: Sec. 1. (a) A provider that is an acute care hospital
licensed under IC 16-21, a state mental health institution under
IC 12-24-1-3, or a private psychiatric institution licensed under
IC 12-25 is a disproportionate share provider if the provider meets
either of the following conditions:
(1) The provider's Medicaid inpatient utilization rate is at least
one (1) standard deviation above the mean Medicaid inpatient
utilization rate for providers receiving Medicaid payments in
Indiana. However, the Medicaid inpatient utilization rate of
providers whose low income utilization rate exceeds twenty-five
percent (25%) must be excluded in calculating the statewide
mean Medicaid inpatient utilization rate.
(2) The provider's low income utilization rate exceeds twenty-five
percent (25%).

disproportionate share provider if the hospital:
(1) has a Medicaid utilization rate greater than one percent (1%);
and
(2) is established and operated under IC 16-22-2 or IC 16-23.
(c) A community mental health center:
(1) that is identified in IC 12-29-2-1;
(2) for which a county provides funds under:
(A) IC 12-29-1-7(b) before January 1, 2004; or
(B) IC 12-29-2 after December 31, 2018;
or from other county sources; and
(3) that provides inpatient services to Medicaid patients;
is a community mental health center disproportionate share provider if
the community mental health center's Medicaid inpatient utilization
rate is greater than one percent (1%).
(d) A disproportionate share provider under IC 12-15-17 must have
at least two (2) obstetricians who have staff privileges and who have
agreed to provide obstetric services under the Medicaid program. For
a hospital located in a rural area (as defined in Section 1886 of the
Social Security Act), an obstetrician includes a physician with staff
privileges at the hospital who has agreed to perform nonemergency
obstetric procedures. However, this obstetric service requirement does

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill regulates hospital billing practices and financial assistance programs, which directly affect seriously ill patients who often incur significant healthcare costs. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, the protections and payment plan requirements can reduce financial burdens on patients receiving complex, ongoing care including palliative services. The bill also mandates charity care notices and limits on garnishment and liens for low-income consumers, indirectly supporting access to care for vulnerable populations often served by palliative care providers.
analysis.summary: SB0317 establishes requirements for hospitals to offer affordable payment plans and provide clear information about charity care programs to patients. It protects low-income consumers from wage garnishment and liens on their primary residence for healthcare debt. These provisions indirectly benefit seriously ill patients, including those receiving palliative care, by improving financial access and reducing economic stress. The bill applies statewide to hospitals meeting revenue thresholds and aims to enhance transparency and fairness in healthcare billing.
key_provisions: Hospitals must offer patients payment plans with terms allowing up to 24 months to pay and monthly payments capped at 10% of gross household income.
Hospitals must develop and provide written notices about charity care programs at intake/discharge and post notices in key hospital areas.
Billing statements must include information about financial assistance availability, contact phone numbers, and web links.

Hospitals with at least $20 million in annual gross patient revenue must provide timely written eligibility determinations and enrollment offers for payment plans or charity care upon patient request.
Unpaid earnings of consumers below 250% of federal poverty level are protected from garnishment for healthcare debt.
Health care debt cannot create a lien against the principal residence of eligible low-income consumers.
Judgments for healthcare debt do not constitute liens on principal residences of qualifying consumers.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it indirectly supports seriously ill patients who often receive palliative services by improving financial protections and access to affordable payment options. By requiring hospitals to offer manageable payment plans and charity care information, the bill reduces financial barriers that can impede access to ongoing symptom management and supportive care. The protections against wage garnishment and liens on primary residences for low-income patients help alleviate economic stress, which is critical for patients and families managing serious illness. These measures can improve care continuity and quality for palliative care populations across hospital settings statewide.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through systemic healthcare financial protections that benefit seriously ill patients without explicitly naming palliative care. It enhances patient rights and affordability, which are key social determinants affecting access to palliative and supportive care. The mandated transparency and communication about financial assistance programs can facilitate earlier engagement with care teams, including palliative specialists. These changes improve the healthcare environment for seriously ill patients by addressing economic barriers and promoting equitable access to hospital-based services.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It centers on hospital billing and financial protections, which are relevant to palliative care policy without falling under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill amends and adds provisions to existing Indiana codes regulating hospital billing practices, charity care, and debt collection, thereby referencing and modifying regulatory frameworks.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0317
Title: Health care debt and costs.
Description: Health care debt and costs. Requires hospitals to do the following: (1) Offer the person who has received health services the opportunity to pay the charges through a payment plan that satisfies certain requirements. (2) Develop a written notice about a charity care program operated by the hospital, provide the notice to patients, and post the notice. (3) Include certain information concerning financial assistance on a billing statement. (4) Requires a hospital that reports an annual gross patient revenue of at least $20,000,000 to provide written notice and information to a person who has requested an eligibility determination concerning a payment plan or charity care. Provides that the unpaid earnings of a consumer who meets specified income eligibility requirements may not be attached by garnishment in satisfaction of: (1) any amount of health care debt owed or alleged to be owed by the consumer; or (2) any amount of the judgment that represents health care debt determined to be owed by the consumer. Provides that: (1) any amount of health care debt owed or alleged to be owed by a consumer; or (2) in an action against a consumer in which a judgment has been entered, any amount of the judgment that represents health care debt determined to be owed by the consumer; does not constitute a lien against the consumer's principal residence for a consumer that meets specified income requirements. Provides that in any action filed in Indiana for the recovery of health care debt owed or alleged to be owed by a consumer, the principal residence of the consumer is not liable to judgment or attachment or to be sold on execution against the consumer.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes broad health care regulatory reforms including Medicaid fraud control, transparency in pricing for clinical laboratories and diagnostic imaging, and payment reforms affecting provider billing and reimbursement. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it impacts seriously ill patients through improved transparency, payment structures, and quality metrics in Medicaid risk-based managed care. These provisions indirectly affect palliative care delivery settings, providers, and patients by influencing access, payment, and quality oversight in health care services relevant to serious illness care.
analysis.summary: HB1003 enacts comprehensive health care reforms in Indiana, including enhanced Medicaid fraud investigations, mandated price transparency for clinical labs and diagnostic imaging, and new payment and billing rules for providers in office settings. It requires quality metrics and accountability safeguards for Medicaid risk-based managed care, which serves many seriously ill patients. The bill also facilitates provisional physician credentialing and prior authorization dispute reporting, improving provider network stability and administrative transparency. These changes indirectly support palliative care by improving care quality, payment fairness, and data transparency statewide.
key_provisions: Establishes Medicaid fraud control unit authority to investigate provider and insurer fraud, abuse, and neglect in Medicaid and board and care facilities.
Requires the Secretary of Family and Social Services to develop quality and outcome metrics and transparency safeguards for Medicaid risk-based managed care programs.
Mandates clinical laboratories and diagnostic imaging facilities to post standardized pricing information for shoppable services by July 31, 2026.
Implements payment reforms requiring qualified providers in office settings to bill on individual provider forms with reimbursement based on physician fee schedules starting January 1, 2026.
Requires provisional credentialing of fully credentialed physicians who change employment or establish new practices in Indiana for up to 60 days to ensure continuity of care.
Creates a reporting system for prior authorization disputes between providers and health plans, with a required report to the legislature by December 1, 2026.
Mandates good faith estimates of nonemergency health care service costs be provided to patients within two business days, improving patient financial transparency.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it indirectly impacts palliative care delivery by improving Medicaid managed care quality oversight, which covers many seriously ill patients who receive palliative services. Enhanced price transparency for diagnostic and laboratory services benefits patients requiring complex care coordination typical in palliative care. Payment reforms and provisional credentialing reduce administrative barriers and support provider stability, facilitating access to specialty care including palliative care. The prior authorization dispute reporting system may reduce delays in care authorization, benefiting seriously ill patients. Overall, these changes improve access, quality, and financial transparency in settings where palliative care is often delivered.

Provisional credentialing supports workforce stability that benefits specialty providers including palliative care clinicians. Prior authorization dispute reporting and audit rights enhance administrative transparency, indirectly supporting timely access to palliative care services. Price transparency for labs and imaging aids patients managing serious illness in navigating care costs.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1003
Title: Health matters.
Description: Health matters. Specifies that the Medicaid fraud control unit's (MFCU) investigation of Medicaid fraud may include the investigation of provider fraud, insurer fraud, duplicate billing, and other instances of fraud. Permits the attorney general to enter into a data sharing agreement with specified state agencies and authorizes the MFCU to analyze this data to carry out its investigative duties. Provides that all complaints made to the MFCU are confidential until an action is filed concerning the complaint. Requires the office of the secretary of family and social services to establish: (1) metrics to assess the quality of care and patient outcomes; and (2) transparency and accountability safeguards; for a specified long term care risk based managed care program. Requires, not later than July 31, 2026, a clinical laboratory and diagnostic imaging facility to post certain pricing information for services determined by the department of insurance. Allows: (1) a manufacturer to provide; and (2) a patient to receive; individualized investigational treatment if certain conditions are met. Requires an Indiana nonprofit hospital system to report a list of facilities that may submit a bill on an institutional provider form and report the facility code for each facility. Adds provisions concerning payments by insurers, health maintenance organizations, employers, and other responsible persons to qualified providers that are providing services in an office setting. Requires good faith estimates for health care services to be provided at least two business days (rather than five business days) before the health care services are scheduled to be provided. Removes language concerning the disclosure of a trade secret from provisions that allow for a health plan sponsor to access and audit claims data. Provides that when a health carrier is in the process of negotiating a health provider contract with a health provider facility or provider, the health carrier must provide certain information to the health provider facility or provider. Prohibits certain provisions from being included in a health provider contract. Allows the department of insurance to: (1) enter into partnerships and joint ventures to encourage best practices in the appropriate and effective use of prior authorization in health care; and (2) receive information regarding prior authorization disputes. Requires the department of insurance to prepare a report with findings and recommendations related to the prior authorization dispute information. Requires, not later than September 1, 2025, the department of insurance to issue a request for information concerning ways to better enable medical consumers to compare and shop for medical and health care services. Provides that an insurer or a health maintenance organization may not deny a claim for reimbursement on the sole basis that the referring provider is an out of network provider. Requires, if a fully credentialed physician becomes employed with another employer or establishes or relocates a medical practice in Indiana, an insurer and health maintenance organization to provisionally credential the physician for 60 days or until the physician is fully credentialed, whichever is earlier. Requires the Indiana department of health, in consultation with the office of technology, to study the feasibility of developing certain standards regarding medical records and data.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes funding mechanisms, grant programs, and workforce development initiatives that indirectly impact palliative care by supporting rural hospitals and health care providers serving seriously ill patients. It creates a health workforce student loan repayment program that includes licensed providers relevant to palliative care, and establishes grant programs for rural hospital clinically integrated networks which could facilitate care coordination including palliative care integration. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, its provisions on hospital funding, workforce incentives, and rural health infrastructure create opportunities to enhance access and quality of palliative care services.
analysis.summary: HB1274 establishes multiple health finance provisions including local tax revenue use for county hospitals, a rural hospital clinically integrated network grant program, and the Indiana rural hospital and critical health care services fund to support rural hospitals. It also creates a health workforce student loan repayment program targeting a broad range of licensed health providers, many of whom deliver care to seriously ill patients. These initiatives indirectly support palliative care by strengthening rural hospital infrastructure, improving workforce recruitment and retention, and fostering integrated care models statewide.
key_provisions: Establishes the Indiana rural hospital and critical health care services fund to award grants to rural hospitals for capital projects, technology upgrades, and operational expenses.
Creates the rural hospital clinically integrated network grant program to support collaboration among rural hospitals and providers for improved patient outcomes and operational sustainability.

Establishes the health workforce student loan repayment program and fund administered by the Indiana Department of Health to repay loans of eligible licensed health providers practicing in shortage areas.
Allows counties with populations under 50,000 to impose local income tax rates dedicated to supporting county and critical access hospitals.
Requires rural hospital clinically integrated networks receiving grants to submit annual reports on fund usage and strategic plan progress.
Urges legislative study committees to explore telehealth expansion, rural workforce training, and funding for emergency and specialty hospital services.
Repeals previous loan forgiveness and mental health service development programs, consolidating workforce incentives under the new repayment program.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it indirectly benefits palliative care delivery by funding rural hospitals and critical access hospitals that serve seriously ill patients who often require palliative care. The establishment of clinically integrated networks promotes care coordination, which can facilitate integration of palliative care services. The health workforce student loan repayment program targets a broad range of licensed providers including nurses, social workers, and physicians, supporting recruitment and retention of professionals essential for palliative care. The bill’s focus on telehealth expansion and technology upgrades also enhances access to palliative care in rural and underserved areas.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through healthcare financing reforms that improve rural hospital sustainability, workforce development programs that include palliative care professionals, and infrastructure grants that enable technology and operational improvements facilitating care coordination. It also promotes telehealth expansion, which benefits seriously ill patients requiring symptom management and specialist consultations remotely. These system-level changes support quality and access improvements for seriously ill populations without explicitly naming palliative care.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general adult hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on rural hospital funding, workforce development, and integrated care networks, which are relevant and permissible areas for palliative care policy tracking.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires the Indiana Department of Health to administer new funds and programs, including rulemaking authority to establish eligibility and administration criteria for the health workforce student loan repayment program.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1274
Title: Health finance matters.
Description: Health finance matters. Adds capital projects, technology upgrades, and operational expenses for certain county hospitals to the definition of "public safety" for purposes of local income tax revenue use. Increases the maximum local income tax that may be imposed in certain counties if a tax rate is adopted for purposes related to certain hospitals located in the county. Establishes the rural hospital clinically integrated network grant program to provide grants to rural hospital clinically integrated networks. Establishes the Indiana rural hospital and critical health care services fund (rural health care services fund) for the purpose of awarding grants to certain rural hospitals. Provides that the Indiana department of health (state department) administers the rural health care services fund. Establishes the following: (1) The health workforce student loan repayment program (program). (2) The health workforce advisory board (advisory board). (3) The health workforce student loan repayment program fund (repayment program fund) for the purpose of providing funds to repay outstanding student loans of certain health providers who meet the program requirements. Provides that the state department shall administer the program and repayment program fund. Establishes: (1) the imposition of fees at the time a license is issued or renewed for certain health profession licenses; and (2) qualifications to receive a student loan repayment award under the program. Provides that, beginning July 1, 2025, the state department and each board included in the program may award a student loan repayment to an eligible applicant who is a provider licensed by the board. Provides that money in the repayment program fund is continuously appropriated. Repeals provisions concerning the following: (1) The primary care physician loan forgiveness program. (2) The mental health services development programs. (3) The dental underserved area and minority recruitment program. Urges the legislative council to assign to an appropriate interim study committee the task of studying topics related to the rural health care services fund. Urges the legislative council to assign to an appropriate study committee the task of studying certain topics related to health care services.

Synopsis:  Health finance matters. Adds capital projects, technology
upgrades, and operational expenses for certain county hospitals to the
definition of "public safety" for purposes of local income tax revenue
use. Increases the maximum local income tax that may be imposed in
certain counties if a tax rate is adopted for purposes related to certain
hospitals located in the county. Establishes the rural hospital clinically
integrated network grant program to provide grants to rural hospital
clinically integrated networks. Establishes the Indiana rural hospital
and critical health care services fund (rural health care services fund)
for the purpose of awarding grants to certain rural hospitals. Provides
that the Indiana department of health (state department) administers the
rural health care services fund. Establishes the following: (1) The
health workforce student loan repayment program (program). (2) The
health workforce advisory board (advisory board). (3) The health
workforce student loan repayment program fund (repayment program
fund) for the purpose of providing funds to repay outstanding student
loans of certain health providers who meet the program requirements.
Provides that the state department shall administer the program and
repayment program fund. Establishes: (1) the imposition of fees at the
time a license is issued or renewed for certain health profession
licenses; and (2) qualifications to receive a student loan repayment
award under the program. Provides that, beginning July 1, 2025, the
state department and each board included in the program may award a
student loan repayment to an eligible applicant who is a provider
licensed by the board. Provides that money in the repayment program
fund is continuously appropriated. Repeals provisions concerning the
