bill.title: Services for the aged and disabled.

extra_metadata.last_action: Public Law 167

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes and reforms community and home care services for aged and disabled populations, including Medicaid waiver programs and managed care arrangements that serve seriously ill individuals. It directly impacts access to home and community-based services, telehealth for chronic care management, and reimbursement policies, all of which are critical components of upstream palliative care delivery. Although it does not explicitly mention palliative care, the populations served and services funded overlap substantially with palliative care needs and settings. The bill also creates infrastructure such as pilot programs and requires coordination with area agencies on aging, presenting opportunities for palliative care integration.
analysis.summary: HB1391 reforms and expands community and home care services for aged and disabled individuals in Indiana, including realignment of area agencies on aging, Medicaid waiver program enhancements, and a Medicaid diversion pilot for telehealth and home modifications. It prioritizes non-Medicaid eligible individuals at risk of institutionalization and authorizes reimbursement for level of care assessments through managed care organizations. These provisions indirectly support palliative care by improving access to home-based services, chronic condition management via telehealth, and coordinated care for seriously ill populations statewide.
key_provisions: Establishes a Medicaid diversion pilot program to evaluate home modification and telehealth enhanced chronic care services provided by area agencies on aging to reduce Medicaid expenditures.

Requires area agencies on aging to prioritize funding to identify at-risk individuals not eligible for Medicaid and provide community and home care services to prevent hospitalization and institutionalization.
Allows the office of the secretary to negotiate reimbursement rates for community and home care services considering provider location and availability.
Permits contracting with area agencies on aging for level of care assessments for Medicaid waivers and risk-based managed care programs.
Amends the definition of community and home care services under the CHOICE program to include a broad range of supportive services aimed at reducing institutional care.
Prohibits requiring CHOICE providers to be Medicaid certified except for certain specified services such as attendant care, clinical therapeutic services, and respite care.
Authorizes study and report on realigning and consolidating area agency on aging planning and service areas to improve service delivery.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: While the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it significantly impacts upstream palliative care by enhancing access to home and community-based services for seriously ill aged and disabled populations. The Medicaid diversion pilot for telehealth and home modifications supports symptom management and chronic care, key components of palliative care. Reimbursement reforms and level of care assessments improve coordination and funding mechanisms that can include palliative care providers. The focus on preventing hospitalization and institutionalization aligns with palliative care goals to maintain quality of life in community settings. Providers, patients, caregivers, and area agencies on aging statewide stand to benefit from these changes.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill affects palliative care indirectly through Medicaid payment reforms, expansion of telehealth for chronic condition management, and strengthening community-based care infrastructure. It supports workforce and provider networks via area agencies on aging and managed care contracts, enabling integration of palliative care services without explicitly naming them. The pilot program and reporting requirements create opportunities to evaluate and potentially expand palliative care-related interventions in home and community settings.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general hospice care (only community and home care services), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on services for aged and disabled populations with potential overlap with palliative care but does not fall under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires the division to adopt rules for coordination of the CHOICE program and involves negotiation of reimbursement rates, implying regulatory activity.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1391
Title: Services for the aged and disabled.
Description: Services for the aged and disabled. Allows the office of the secretary of family and social services (office of the secretary) to study and prepare a report containing recommendations for realigning and consolidating the local area agency on aging (area agency) planning and service areas. Amends the definition of "community and home care services" for purposes of community and home options to institutional care for the elderly and disabled program (CHOICE). Prohibits the division of aging from requiring a CHOICE provider to be certified under the Medicaid program or a Medicaid waiver program. Creates an exception for a provider of certain services. Requires an area agency to prioritize CHOICE funding to identify specified individuals and provide community and home care services to these individuals. Requires the office of the secretary, in negotiating reimbursement rates for CHOICE services, to consider the location and availability of service providers. Authorizes the office of the secretary to establish a Medicaid diversion pilot program to evaluate the effectiveness of home modification and telehealth enhanced chronic care services provided by specified area agencies in reducing Medicaid expenditures. Allows the office of the secretary, a managed care organization that has contracted with the office of Medicaid policy and planning, and a person who has contracted with a certain managed care organization or the office of the secretary to contract with an area agency to provide and receive reimbursement for a level of care assessment for the: (1) health and wellness Medicaid waiver; (2) traumatic brain injury Medicaid waiver; and (3) risk based managed care program for the covered population.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill regulates licensure and employment standards for home health agencies, nurse aides, and other unlicensed healthcare workers, which are key providers in palliative care delivery settings. It also updates enforcement standards for hospitals and outpatient surgical centers, and addresses reporting and registry requirements affecting healthcare workforce quality. Although it does not explicitly mention palliative care, these provisions indirectly impact the quality and safety of care for seriously ill patients receiving palliative services in home and facility settings.
analysis.summary: HB1457 updates regulatory standards for the Indiana Department of Health, including enforcement of facility design codes, criminal background checks for home health and nurse aides, and reporting requirements for deaths and mental health records. These changes enhance patient safety and workforce integrity in home health and healthcare facilities, indirectly benefiting seriously ill patients who receive palliative care. The bill also governs vendor selection for the WIC nutrition program and modifies child fatality review committee membership, reflecting a broad public health scope with statewide impact.
key_provisions: Requires criminal background checks and prohibits employment of individuals convicted of specified crimes as home health aides, nurse aides, or unlicensed healthcare workers.
Mandates the Indiana Department of Health to investigate reports of convictions and remove unfit individuals from the state nurse aide registry.
Specifies use of updated Facility Guidelines Institute and NFPA codes for hospital and ambulatory outpatient surgical center design enforcement.
Establishes procedures for electronic submission and certification of birth and death records, including stillbirths, by attending healthcare professionals.
Amends membership and removes expiration of the statewide maternal mortality review committee and modifies the statewide child fatality review committee.
Requires the state department to select WIC program vendors based on federal criteria and publish selection criteria annually.
Allows disclosure of mental health records without patient consent to certain entities for care coordination, safety planning, and legal purposes.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly impacts palliative care by strengthening workforce protections through rigorous background checks and registry maintenance for home health and nurse aides, who are frontline providers in palliative care settings. Enhanced enforcement of facility design standards supports safe environments for seriously ill patients receiving care in hospitals and outpatient centers. Improved death and mental health record reporting facilitates better data for care quality and safety monitoring. These changes benefit patients, providers, and facilities statewide by promoting safer, higher-quality care delivery environments relevant to palliative care.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it affects key healthcare workforce regulations and facility standards that influence care quality for seriously ill patients. The criminal background check and registry provisions ensure that home health and nurse aides providing palliative and supportive care meet safety standards. Updated facility design codes impact the physical environment where palliative care is delivered. Reporting improvements for deaths and mental health records support care coordination and quality oversight.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general adult hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. Its focus on workforce, facility standards, and public health reporting falls within relevant palliative care policy areas.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill references enforcement of Facility Guidelines Institute and NFPA codes as part of hospital and ambulatory surgical center licensure, and mandates rulemaking for WIC vendor contracts and auto-injectable epinephrine course approval.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1457
Title: Indiana department of health.
Description: Indiana department of health. Specifies that provisions of law governing the office of administrative law proceedings apply to the Indiana department of health (state department) in matters concerning the involuntary transfer or discharge of a resident of a health facility. Specifies conditions for the use of updated publications for design enforcement by the state department in the regulation of hospitals and ambulatory outpatient surgical centers. Amends the list of crimes or acts that preclude a home health aide, nurse aide, or other unlicensed employee from employment at a home health agency and certain health care facilities. Amends the list of crimes that preclude a person from operating a home health agency or personal services agency. Requires the state department to: (1) investigate any report that a nurse aide or home health aide has been convicted of a certain crime; and (2) remove the individual from the state nurse aide registry. Makes it a Class A infraction for a person convicted of a certain crime to knowingly or intentionally apply for a job as a home health aide or other unlicensed employee at a home health agency or certain health care facilities. For provisions concerning the women, infants, and children nutrition program (WIC program), defines "WIC vendor agreement". Requires the state department to: (1) select WIC program vendors based on selection criteria set forth in federal regulations; (2) review the selection criteria annually; (3) include the selection criteria in the WIC state plan; and (4) publish the selection criteria on the state department's website. For purposes of submitting a death record of a stillborn, requires the physician, physician assistant, or advanced practice registered nurse (APRN) last in attendance to initiate the document process unless the physician, physician assistant, or APRN was not present upon the deceased. Includes reporting to local child fatality review teams, the statewide child fatality review committee, local fetal-infant mortality review teams, and suicide and overdose fatality review teams for the release of mental health records without the consent of the patient. Requires the state department to: (1) approve courses concerning auto-injectable epinephrine that meet criteria established by the state department (rather than courses offered by an approved organization as defined in current law); and (2) publish the criteria on its website. Removes a provision allowing the state department to contract with a third party to create a certificate of completion for a course. Removes the expiration of the statewide maternal mortality review committee. Amends the membership of the statewide child fatality review committee.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill addresses maternal health with provisions that include coverage for postpartum mental health conditions, Medicaid reimbursement for doula and certified medical interpretation services, and establishment of programs supporting incarcerated pregnant women and stillbirth prevention. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it impacts seriously ill patients—specifically pregnant and postpartum women with mental health needs—and creates healthcare infrastructure and payment reforms relevant to symptom management and supportive care. These elements indirectly affect palliative care by improving access to behavioral health resources, care coordination, and supportive services for a vulnerable population.
analysis.summary: SB0522 establishes comprehensive maternal health policies including prohibiting step therapy for postpartum mental health drugs, mandating insurance coverage for postpartum mental health screenings and treatments, and Medicaid reimbursement for doula and medical interpretation services. It creates the Officer Breann Leath Memorial Prison Nursery for incarcerated pregnant women, a telephone assistance line for mothers with behavioral health issues, and a stillbirth prevention pilot program. These provisions indirectly support palliative care by enhancing behavioral health access and supportive services for seriously ill postpartum women statewide, with dedicated funding and programmatic infrastructure.
key_provisions: Prohibits step therapy protocols for prescription drugs treating postpartum mental health conditions in state employee health plans and insurance policies.
Requires coverage for postpartum mental health screenings and treatments, tubal ligation, and vasectomy procedures under state employee health plans and insurance.
Establishes a grant program administered by the Indiana Housing and Community Development Authority to fund lactation rooms in public buildings.
Creates the Officer Breann Leath Memorial Prison Nursery within a correctional facility to support incarcerated pregnant women and their infants up to 30 months.
Mandates Medicaid reimbursement for doula services and certified medical interpretation services for Medicaid recipients with limited English proficiency.
Establishes a telephone assistance line program for mothers experiencing behavioral health issues to connect with healthcare practitioners.
Creates a stillbirth prevention pilot program focused on education about fetal movement tracking in the third trimester, with dedicated funding and reporting requirements.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: This bill indirectly impacts palliative care by enhancing access to behavioral health services and supportive care for postpartum women, a population that may experience serious illness and complex symptom burdens. The prohibition of step therapy for postpartum mental health medications improves timely access to appropriate treatments, which aligns with palliative care principles of symptom relief and quality of life. Medicaid reimbursement for doula and medical interpretation services supports culturally competent, patient-centered care coordination. The prison nursery program addresses the needs of incarcerated pregnant women, a vulnerable group requiring specialized care. The stillbirth prevention program and maternal health education initiatives create opportunities for integrating palliative approaches in maternal and perinatal care settings. Overall, the bill supports workforce development, payment reforms, quality standards, and public awareness that can benefit palliative care delivery in maternal health contexts.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through healthcare system reforms that improve access to mental health and supportive services for seriously ill postpartum women without explicitly mentioning palliative care. Payment policy changes such as prohibiting step therapy and expanding Medicaid coverage for doula and interpretation services affect care delivery and coordination. The establishment of specialized programs for incarcerated pregnant women and stillbirth prevention creates infrastructure that could incorporate palliative care principles. Public awareness and education efforts on fetal movement tracking and maternal behavioral health indirectly support early intervention and symptom management.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It specifically addresses maternal health, behavioral health, and supportive care services, which are relevant to palliative care without falling under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires the Department of Correction to adopt rules governing the operation of the prison nursery and minimum standards for county jails, including provision of menstrual discharge collection devices. It also mandates rulemaking for Medicaid pregnancy services and insurance coverage policies.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0522
Title: Maternal health matters.
Description: Maternal health matters. Prohibits step therapy protocol for prescription drugs prescribed for the treatment of postpartum mental health conditions. Requires a state employee health plan, a policy of accident and sickness insurance, and a health maintenance organization contract to provide coverage for: (1) postpartum mental health conditions; (2) a tubal ligation procedure; and (3) a vasectomy procedure; for certain individuals. Establishes a grant program to promote the installation of lactation rooms in public buildings. Requires the Indiana housing and community development authority (IHCDA) to administer the grant program. Authorizes public agencies to apply for grants. Establishes the Officer Breann Leath Memorial Prison Nursery (nursery) within a correctional facility determined by the commissioner of the department of correction (DOC). Specifies the criteria for operation, design, and implementation of the nursery and minimum standards that govern the nursery. Requires the DOC to provide an annual report to the legislative council concerning the nursery. Amends the statute requiring the DOC to adopt rules governing minimum standards for county jails to include the provision of menstrual discharge collection devices to inmates. Establishes the incarcerated women's maternal health fund to provide funds to support the nursery. Provides for Medicaid reimbursement for certified medical interpretation services for Medicaid recipients who have limited English proficiency when receiving Medicaid covered services from a Medicaid provider. Requires Medicaid pregnancy services to include reimbursement for doula services. Establishes the telephone assistance line for mothers program for the purpose of providing a telephone assistance line for mothers who are experiencing behavioral health issues to connect with health care practitioners to obtain behavioral health resources. Establishes the stillbirth prevention through fetal movement pilot program (program) for the purpose of providing evidence based information on the importance of tracking fetal movement in the third trimester of pregnancy to prevent stillbirths, to be administered by the Indiana department of health (state department). Allows the state department to award grants to increase education and the distribution of materials on tracking fetal movement in the third trimester of pregnancy. Requires grantees to report specified information on a quarterly and annual basis. Creates a fund and appropriates $250,000 for the program. Expires the program on December 31, 2027. Appropriates $5,000,000 to the IHCDA for deposit in the lactation room grant fund. Makes a continuing appropriation.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes Medicaid enrollment assistance for incarcerated individuals prior to release and ensures continuity of Medicaid coverage including federally mandated services before and after release, which benefits seriously ill populations who often experience incarceration. It also creates and amends Medicaid advisory commissions that include beneficiary representation, providing infrastructure for policy input that could encompass palliative care concerns. Additionally, the bill mandates pediatric first aid and CPR training for child care providers, indirectly supporting pediatric care quality, which may intersect with pediatric palliative care settings.
analysis.summary: SB0486 mandates sheriffs to assist incarcerated individuals in applying for Medicaid prior to release to ensure coverage continuity, including for children in juvenile facilities. It establishes a Medicaid beneficiary advisory commission to advise on Medicaid policy and administration, potentially influencing palliative care access and quality. The bill also requires pediatric first aid and CPR training for child care providers, supporting pediatric health safety. These provisions indirectly impact seriously ill populations by improving Medicaid access and creating advisory infrastructure statewide.
key_provisions: Requires sheriffs to assist incarcerated individuals eligible for Medicaid in applying for coverage prior to release to ensure continuity of care.
Mandates the division of family resources to ensure children released from juvenile detention receive federally mandated Medicaid services 30 days before and after release.
Creates the Medicaid beneficiary advisory commission composed of Medicaid beneficiaries and family caregivers to advise on Medicaid policy and administration.
Requires insurers to accept Medicaid claims for three years and prohibits denial of claims solely due to lack of prior authorization, improving Medicaid payment processes.
Mandates pediatric first aid and pediatric CPR training for all child care provider employees, with at least one certified adult present during child care hours.
Amends membership and duties of Medicaid advisory commissions to include diverse stakeholder representation including pediatric and mental health organizations.
Repeals tuberculosis testing requirements for child care provider employees but strengthens pediatric emergency training requirements.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: While the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it indirectly supports seriously ill patients by improving Medicaid enrollment and coverage continuity for incarcerated and juvenile populations, who often have complex health needs including serious illness. The creation of the Medicaid beneficiary advisory commission provides a platform for beneficiary input that could influence palliative care policy and access. Pediatric first aid and CPR training requirements enhance the safety and clinical preparedness of child care settings, which may benefit pediatric palliative care populations. Overall, the bill improves healthcare access, payment processes, and workforce training that can positively affect palliative care delivery in community and correctional settings statewide.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through Medicaid payment and eligibility reforms that facilitate access for vulnerable populations, including incarcerated individuals and children in juvenile facilities. The advisory commissions established create infrastructure for policy development that could incorporate palliative care priorities. Workforce training mandates in pediatric emergency care indirectly support pediatric palliative care by enhancing clinical skills in child care settings. These system-level changes affect seriously ill populations without explicitly naming palliative care.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on Medicaid enrollment, payment, advisory commissions, and pediatric emergency training, all relevant to palliative care policy without falling under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill references compliance with federal Medicaid law and state regulations for Medicaid claims processing, Medicaid eligibility, and child care provider certification standards including pediatric CPR and first aid training.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0486
Title: Family and social services matters.
Description: Family and social services matters. Requires a sheriff to assist an individual who: (1) has been incarcerated for at least 30 days in a: (A) county jail; (B) community based correctional facility for children; (C) juvenile detention facility; or (D) secure facility other than a child caring institution; and (2) is eligible for Medicaid; in applying for Medicaid before the individual's release from the facility. Provides that if a child loses Medicaid coverage while confined in a juvenile detention facility or secure facility, the division of family resources shall, upon receiving notice that the child will be released, take action necessary ensure that the child is eligible to receive specified federally mandated services for 30 days before and after the child's release. Requires an insurer to respond within 60 days to an inquiry from the office of Medicaid policy and planning regarding a Medicaid claim that is made within three years from the date on which the service that is the subject of the claim was provided. Provides that an insurer other than Medicare, Medicare Advantage, or Medicare Part D may not deny a Medicaid claim solely due to lack of prior authorization in accordance with federal Medicaid law. Provides that the requirement that an individual who receives payment for medical expenses from Medicaid must cede to the state the individual's rights to third party payment for the medical expenses extends to settlement amounts for both past medical expenses and rights to payment of future medical expenses. Amends the duties, membership, and terms of office of the Medicaid advisory commission. Creates the Medicaid beneficiary advisory commission. Repeals a provision requiring that employees of a child care provider be tested for tuberculosis in order for the child care provider to be eligible to receive voucher payments under the federal Child Care and Development Fund program. Provides the following with regard to a licensed child care center, licensed child care home, or registered child care ministry (child care provider): (1) Requires all employees of a child care provider to be trained in pediatric first aid and pediatric cardiopulmonary resuscitation applicable to all age groups of children cared for by the child care provider. (2) Requires at least one adult who is certified in pediatric cardiopulmonary resuscitation applicable to all age groups of children cared for by the child care provider to be present at all times when a child is in the care of the child care provider. Amends the membership of the division of mental health and addiction planning and advisory council.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill regulates prior authorization requirements for health care services, which directly affects access to timely care for seriously ill patients, including those receiving palliative care. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, the provisions on utilization review, authorization timelines, and prohibitions on denial based on out-of-network referrals impact how palliative care services are authorized and reimbursed. The bill's focus on streamlining prior authorization processes and ensuring timely decisions can reduce barriers to palliative care access and continuity.
analysis.summary: SB0480 establishes comprehensive prior authorization requirements for health plans and utilization review entities, including prohibiting prior authorization for the first 12 physical therapy or chiropractic visits per episode of care and mandating timely responses to authorization requests. It prohibits denial of claims solely due to out-of-network referring providers and requires transparency and reporting on prior authorization decisions. These changes indirectly facilitate improved access and payment processes for palliative care and other services for seriously ill patients statewide by reducing administrative delays and denials.
key_provisions: Prohibits utilization review entities from requiring prior authorization for the first 12 physical therapy or chiropractic visits per new episode of care.
Requires health plans to accept prior authorization requests electronically and respond within 24-48 hours for urgent and non-urgent services respectively.
Mandates that claims cannot be denied solely because the referring provider is out-of-network.
Establishes requirements for clinical peer review of adverse determinations and peer-to-peer review processes.
Requires utilization review entities to publicly post prior authorization criteria and provide advance notice of changes.
Sets authorization validity for at least one year and requires honoring prior authorizations during health plan transitions.
Provides protections for emergency health care services and automatic authorization if deadlines are missed.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it directly affects access to palliative care services by regulating prior authorization processes that often delay or deny needed care for seriously ill patients. The prohibition on denying claims based solely on out-of-network referrals supports continuity of care for patients who may see specialty palliative providers outside narrow networks. Timely authorization decisions and peer review requirements improve the likelihood that symptom management, rehabilitation, and supportive therapies integral to palliative care are approved without undue delay. Transparency and standardized forms reduce administrative burden on providers delivering palliative care. These provisions benefit patients, providers, and health plans across Indiana healthcare settings, including hospitals, outpatient clinics, and home-based care.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care by improving healthcare system processes that affect seriously ill patients, such as authorization timelines, appeals, and claim denials. It enhances payment system transparency and fairness, which can indirectly improve reimbursement for palliative care services. The inclusion of emergency health care service protections and clinical peer review mechanisms supports quality and access for complex care needs without explicitly naming palliative care.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It addresses insurance prior authorization processes broadly applicable to many health services, including palliative care, without exclusion criteria triggers.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill references existing insurance regulations and requires the department to establish and maintain standardized prior authorization forms and processes, as well as mandates compliance with prior authorization timelines and transparency requirements.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0480
Title: Prior authorization.
Description: Prior authorization. Sets forth requirements for a utilization review entity that requires prior authorization of a health care service. Prohibits a utilization review entity from requiring prior authorization for the first 12 physical therapy or chiropractic visits of each new episode of care. Provides that a claim for reimbursement for a covered service or item provided to an insured or enrollee may not be denied on the sole basis that the referring provider is an out of network provider. Repeals superseded provisions regarding prior authorization. Makes corresponding changes.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill extensively reforms Medicaid eligibility, enrollment, and oversight in Indiana, which directly affects access to healthcare services for seriously ill patients, including those who may benefit from palliative care. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care or hospice, it impacts Medicaid payment policies, presumptive eligibility processes in hospitals, and coverage under the Healthy Indiana Plan, all of which influence the delivery and financing of care for seriously ill populations. The bill also establishes performance standards and appeals processes for hospitals making presumptive eligibility determinations, which can facilitate timely access to care for patients with serious illnesses.
analysis.summary: SB0002 reforms Indiana's Medicaid program by enhancing oversight, enforcing eligibility verification, and establishing hospital performance standards for presumptive eligibility determinations. It modifies reimbursement policies allowing providers to be paid for claims prior to benefit start dates and governs the Healthy Indiana Plan's eligibility and enrollment rules. These changes indirectly impact palliative care by potentially improving access and continuity of care for seriously ill Medicaid recipients statewide. Key provisions include annual reporting on Medicaid fraud and eligibility enforcement, hospital accountability for presumptive eligibility, and stricter eligibility redetermination processes.
key_provisions: Requires annual reporting on Medicaid improper payments, fraud, waste, and abuse to oversight and budget committees.
Establishes performance standards and an appeals process for hospitals making presumptive Medicaid eligibility determinations.
Allows reimbursement to providers for certified medical claims incurred up to 30 days before Medicaid benefits begin.
Mandates data matching and verification of income, residency, and other eligibility criteria to reduce improper Medicaid enrollment.
Sets eligibility criteria and enrollment rules for the Healthy Indiana Plan, including work and caretaker requirements.
Requires the office of the secretary to conduct frequent eligibility redeterminations based on data from multiple state and federal sources.
Imposes corrective actions and mandatory training for hospitals failing to meet presumptive eligibility standards.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it indirectly affects access to palliative care services by strengthening Medicaid eligibility verification and enrollment processes, which can reduce gaps in coverage for seriously ill patients. The hospital presumptive eligibility standards facilitate quicker access to Medicaid coverage, potentially enabling timely initiation of palliative care. Reimbursement provisions for claims prior to benefit start dates support continuity of care during eligibility transitions. The Healthy Indiana Plan's inclusion of individuals caring for persons with serious medical conditions expands coverage to caregivers, indirectly supporting family-centered care. Overall, the bill impacts providers, hospitals, and Medicaid recipients statewide by enhancing payment and quality oversight mechanisms relevant to palliative care delivery.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care by reforming Medicaid enrollment and eligibility processes, which affect seriously ill patients' access to services without explicitly mentioning palliative care. It includes hospital performance standards and provider reimbursement policies that influence care delivery settings where palliative care is often provided. The Healthy Indiana Plan's eligibility criteria include caregivers of individuals with serious medical conditions, indirectly supporting palliative care populations. These systemic Medicaid changes create infrastructure opportunities for integrating palliative care within Medicaid-funded services.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It centers on Medicaid program administration, eligibility, and payment policies, which are relevant to palliative care access and delivery.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0002
Title: Medicaid matters.
Description: Medicaid matters. Requires the office of the secretary of family and social services (office) to report specified Medicaid data to the Medicaid oversight committee. Requires the office to annually prepare and present a report to the budget committee concerning the enforcement of the Medicaid five year look back period. Prohibits specified persons from advertising or otherwise marketing the Medicaid program. Provides that the office may adopt rules concerning permissible advertising or marketing indicating participation in the Medicaid program by a person that has contracted with the office. Allows the office to reimburse medical providers at the appropriate Medicaid fee schedule rate for certified medical claims prior to the beginning of benefits, provided the claims satisfy certain conditions. Repeals language allowing for marketing of the Medicaid program. Requires the office to receive and review data from specified federal and state agencies concerning Medicaid recipients to determine whether circumstances have changed that affect Medicaid eligibility for recipients and to perform a redetermination. Requires the office to establish: (1) performance standards for hospitals that make presumptive eligibility determinations and sets out action for when hospitals do not comply with the standards; and (2) an appeals procedure for hospitals that dispute the violation determination. Sets out a hospital's responsibilities when making a presumptive eligibility determination. Imposes corrective action and restrictions for failing to meet presumptive eligibility standards. Specifies requirements, allowances, and limitations for the healthy Indiana plan.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes Medicaid reimbursement for certified medical interpretation services for Medicaid recipients with limited English proficiency, which indirectly supports palliative care by improving communication access for seriously ill patients. Effective communication is essential in palliative care to understand patient needs, preferences, and to provide symptom management and advance care planning. Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it impacts healthcare delivery for vulnerable populations, including those receiving palliative services.
analysis.summary: HB1464 requires the Indiana Secretary of Family and Social Services to provide Medicaid reimbursement for certified medical interpretation services for Medicaid recipients with limited English proficiency. It mandates the creation of a community advisory committee to guide implementation. This bill indirectly benefits palliative care by enhancing communication access for seriously ill Medicaid patients, improving quality of care and patient-provider interactions statewide.
key_provisions: Requires Medicaid reimbursement for certified medical interpretation services for Medicaid recipients with limited English proficiency.
Mandates the office of the secretary to ensure Medicaid providers can access scheduling for interpretation services.
Establishes a community advisory committee consisting of stakeholders and Medicaid healthcare providers to advise on interpretation services.
Requires the office to apply for any necessary federal state plan amendments or waivers to implement the reimbursement.
Effective date set for July 1, 2025.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: While the bill does not explicitly address palliative care, it improves access to certified medical interpretation services for Medicaid patients with limited English proficiency, a population that includes many seriously ill individuals receiving palliative care. Enhanced communication facilitates better symptom assessment, advance care planning, and shared decision-making, which are core components of palliative care. The advisory committee infrastructure may also provide a platform to incorporate palliative care perspectives in service delivery improvements. Providers and patients statewide benefit from improved access and reimbursement for interpretation services, indirectly supporting quality palliative care delivery.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: This bill impacts palliative care through healthcare system changes that improve communication access for seriously ill patients who have limited English proficiency. By establishing Medicaid reimbursement for interpretation services, it addresses a key barrier to quality care without explicitly mentioning palliative care. The community advisory committee creates infrastructure that could include palliative care stakeholders to further enhance service delivery.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, hospice care (general or pediatric), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on Medicaid reimbursement for interpretation services, which is relevant to palliative care indirectly.

special_flags.regulation_details: Requires the office of the secretary to apply for federal approval of state plan amendments or waivers necessary to implement Medicaid reimbursement for interpretation services.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill directly addresses Medicaid reimbursement policies for children's hospitals, including those providing inpatient and outpatient services to patients under 19 years old. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, the reimbursement changes for pediatric hospitals impact the financial viability and access to care for seriously ill children who may receive pediatric palliative care services. Extending reimbursement provisions for out-of-state children's hospitals indirectly supports pediatric palliative and hospice care by ensuring continued Medicaid coverage and funding for these specialized facilities.
analysis.summary: HB1024 extends the expiration date for Medicaid reimbursement provisions applicable to certain out-of-state children's hospitals from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2027. This legislation ensures continued Medicaid funding for inpatient and outpatient services at children's hospitals serving patients under 19, including those who may require pediatric palliative care. By maintaining reimbursement rates comparable to Medicare and factoring in high-cost cases, the bill supports financial stability of children's hospitals, indirectly benefiting seriously ill pediatric patients. The scope impacts Medicaid recipients statewide who access pediatric hospital services, including cross-border care.
key_provisions: Extends Medicaid reimbursement provisions for out-of-state children's hospitals from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2027.

Requires factoring in cost outlier cases to adjust reimbursement, including retroactive payments.
Applies to inpatient and outpatient Medicaid services for recipients under 19 years old at qualifying children's hospitals.
Allows the Medicaid office to adopt rules necessary to implement these reimbursement provisions.

This financial support helps maintain access to specialized pediatric services, including palliative and hospice care, at both in-state and out-of-state hospitals. The reimbursement methodology accounting for high-cost cases supports hospitals managing complex pediatric patients who often require palliative interventions. The bill benefits pediatric patients, hospital providers, and Medicaid programs by stabilizing funding and access to critical pediatric specialty care.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill affects healthcare financing structures that support pediatric hospitals serving seriously ill children, which is a key setting for pediatric palliative care delivery. By extending reimbursement policies and including cost outlier adjustments, it indirectly supports access to comprehensive care for children with serious illness. This payment policy change influences hospital financial viability and capacity to provide specialized services without explicitly mentioning palliative care.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general adult hospice, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It relates to pediatric hospital reimbursement, which includes pediatric palliative and hospice care, an included category.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill directly affects access to prescription medications for individuals with advanced, metastatic cancer, a population commonly served by palliative care. By prohibiting prior authorization requirements that delay access to appropriate cancer treatments and symptom management drugs, it indirectly supports timely symptom relief and quality of life improvements central to palliative care. Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, its provisions impact seriously ill patients and the payment systems that cover their care.
analysis.summary: HB1062 prohibits state employee health plans, accident and sickness insurance policies, and health maintenance organizations from requiring patients with advanced, metastatic cancer to fail prior therapies before covering certain FDA-approved cancer prescriptions. This change facilitates faster access to appropriate cancer treatments and symptom management medications, which can improve quality of life for seriously ill patients. The bill's statewide application affects insurance coverage policies, potentially benefiting patients receiving palliative care by reducing administrative barriers to medication access.
key_provisions: Prohibits state employee health plans from requiring failure of a prior prescription drug before covering new cancer medications for advanced, metastatic cancer.
Extends the prohibition to accident and sickness insurance policies covering prescription drugs for advanced, metastatic cancer.
Applies the same prohibition to health maintenance organizations providing prescription drug coverage for advanced, metastatic cancer.
Defines advanced, metastatic cancer and associated conditions to include symptoms or side effects that jeopardize patient health if untreated.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1106
Title: Medicaid buy-in.
Description: Medicaid buy-in. Amends the definition of "countable resources" for purposes of the Medicaid buy-in program (program). Removes consideration of income in determining an individual's eligibility for participation in the program. Requires the office of the secretary of family and social services (office of the secretary) to apply for a state plan amendment or waiver to implement this provision. Increases the maximum age to be eligible for participation in the program from 64 years of age to 67 years of age. Allows a recipient's participation in an employment network recognized by the federal Social Security Administration to qualify as participating with an approved provider of employment services. Changes the monthly maximum premium that a recipient must pay. Requires that the premium scale be promulgated by administrative rule. Allows the office of the secretary to annually review the premium amount that a recipient must pay in the program. (Current law requires annual review of the premium amount.) Specifies changes in circumstances that must result in an adjustment of the premium. Specifies that a recipient in the program is eligible for the same services as offered in the Medicaid program. States that an individual's participation in the program does not preclude the individual from participating in a Medicaid waiver program. Specifies that a recipient of the program may simultaneously participate in a Medicaid waiver program and requires the office of the secretary to individually determine eligibility for both programs based on the individual's medical need requirements.
Status: 1
Status Date: 2025-01-08
Sponsors: Edward Clere, Robb Greene, Chris Campbell

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes a statewide Alzheimer's disease and dementia education program through the Indiana Department of Health, targeting public and healthcare provider education. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it addresses populations with serious neurodegenerative illnesses who often require palliative care services. The focus on educating healthcare providers about diagnosis, treatment, care planning, and research advances creates indirect opportunities to improve palliative care integration for dementia patients.
analysis.summary: HB1076 requires the Indiana Department of Health to collaborate with national and local partners to educate the public and healthcare providers about Alzheimer's disease and dementia, including signs, risk factors, diagnosis, treatment, and care planning. This statewide education initiative indirectly supports palliative care by enhancing provider knowledge and public awareness of serious neurodegenerative conditions that commonly require symptom management and supportive care. The bill also authorizes acceptance of grants to fund these educational efforts, potentially expanding resources relevant to palliative care stakeholders.
key_provisions: Requires the Indiana Department of Health to collaborate with a national Alzheimer's and dementia organization for public education.
Mandates identification and collaboration with additional partners including local health departments, aging division, healthcare providers, insurers, and community organizations.
Requires outreach and education programs targeting healthcare providers on diagnosis, treatment, research advances, and care planning.
Obligates publication of educational materials on the state department's website.
Allows the state department to accept grants, services, and property from public and private entities to support education efforts.
Authorizes seeking federal waivers to maximize funding for Alzheimer's and dementia education.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly address palliative care, it indirectly benefits palliative care by improving education and awareness among healthcare providers and the public about Alzheimer's disease and dementia, conditions that often require palliative approaches. Enhanced provider training on care planning and symptom management can facilitate earlier and more effective palliative care integration. The statewide educational infrastructure and partnerships established may serve as a foundation for incorporating palliative care principles into dementia care. Patients with serious neurodegenerative illnesses and their caregivers stand to benefit from improved knowledge and resources.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: This bill impacts palliative care through healthcare workforce education and public awareness campaigns focused on a serious illness population without explicitly mentioning palliative care. It creates infrastructure for provider training and community outreach that can improve quality of care and care coordination for seriously ill dementia patients. The involvement of diverse partners and funding mechanisms may enable expansion of supportive services relevant to palliative care.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, hospice care (general or pediatric), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. Its focus on education about Alzheimer's and dementia is relevant to serious illness care and does not fall under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill references existing health department statutory authority and requires collaboration and publication of educational materials, implying regulatory oversight and potential development of related guidelines.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill mandates insurance coverage for emergency medical services (EMS) provided as part of mobile integrated healthcare programs, which often serve seriously ill and homebound patients who may benefit from palliative care integration. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care or hospice, the inclusion of mobile integrated healthcare within state employee health plans and accident and sickness insurance policies indirectly affects access to advanced life support and emergency care for patients with serious illness. The bill also addresses reimbursement parity and scope of practice for EMS providers, which can influence care coordination and service delivery models relevant to palliative care populations.
analysis.summary: HB1587 requires state employee health plans and certain insurance policies to cover emergency medical services, including those delivered through mobile integrated healthcare programs. This expands reimbursement for advanced life support services regardless of patient transport, potentially improving access to urgent care for seriously ill patients in community settings. The bill indirectly supports palliative care by facilitating integrated emergency and mobile healthcare services that can complement symptom management and crisis intervention. Its statewide scope affects insurance coverage and EMS provider reimbursement policies.
key_provisions: Requires state employee health plans to reimburse emergency medical services including those provided via mobile integrated healthcare programs.
Mandates accident and sickness insurance policies and health maintenance organization contracts to reimburse EMS provided as part of mobile integrated healthcare.
Specifies reimbursement for advanced life support services regardless of patient transport status.
Allows only one claim reimbursement per patient encounter, prioritizing the EMS provider delivering majority of advanced life support.
Grants authority to the state personnel department to adopt implementing rules.
Repeals requirement for health carriers to conduct annual public forums.
Amends definitions related to small employer group health insurance affecting coverage scope.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly benefits palliative care by ensuring insurance coverage and reimbursement for EMS services delivered through mobile integrated healthcare programs, which can provide urgent symptom management and crisis intervention for seriously ill patients outside hospital settings. This supports care continuity and may reduce unnecessary hospitalizations for palliative populations. The reimbursement provisions enhance financial viability of EMS providers engaging in community-based care models relevant to palliative care integration. Providers, patients with serious illness, and health plans statewide are affected by these coverage and payment reforms.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: Though palliative care is not explicitly mentioned, the bill's expansion of insurance coverage for mobile integrated healthcare EMS services impacts seriously ill and homebound patients who often require coordinated symptom management and emergency care. Changes to reimbursement and coverage policies affect healthcare financing and service delivery models that can include palliative care providers. The bill also influences quality standards by defining scope and reimbursement rules for EMS, indirectly shaping care for seriously ill populations.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on insurance coverage for emergency medical services and mobile integrated healthcare, which are relevant to palliative care populations without falling under excluded categories.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill authorizes the state personnel department to adopt rules under IC 4-22-2 to implement coverage and reimbursement provisions for emergency medical services within state employee health plans.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1587
Title: Insurance matters.
Description: Insurance matters. Provides that the director of the state personnel department may make a determination to provide coverage under the state employee health plan for emergency medical services as part of a mobile integrated healthcare program. Provides that the requirement for a policy of accident and sickness insurance and a health maintenance organization contract to provide reimbursement for emergency medical services includes emergency medical services that are performed or provided as part of a mobile integrated healthcare program. Repeals a provision that requires the department of insurance to maintain an electronic system for the collection and storage of information concerning transactions involving residential property. Provides that the article regarding consumer data protection does not apply to any organization exempt from taxation under Section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code that is: (1) established to detect or prevent insurance related crime or fraud; and (2) subject to a memorandum of understanding with a statewide law enforcement agency. Changes the deadline for the Indiana Public Employers' Plan, Inc., to apply to the insurance commissioner for a certificate of authority to transact business as a domestic tax exempt reciprocal insurance company from before December 31, 2026, to before December 31, 2030. Repeals the statute requiring carriers of health insurance plans to conduct annual public forums. Provides that provisions requiring a notice of material change apply to personal automobile or homeowner's policies that are issued, delivered, amended, or renewed after June 30, 2026. Amends the definition of "small employer" in the chapter regarding small employer group health insurance. Makes corresponding changes.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill addresses Medicaid reimbursement parity between hospital outpatient services and physician office services, which indirectly affects payment for services that may include palliative care delivered in outpatient settings. It also requires reporting and oversight related to hospital mergers and physician employment, which can impact healthcare delivery structures relevant to seriously ill patients. Additionally, the bill mandates a report on expanding site neutral reimbursement to commercial insurance, a policy area that could influence access and affordability of palliative care services.
analysis.summary: SB0370 requires Medicaid to reimburse outpatient hospital services at rates equivalent to those paid for the same services in physician offices, with certain exceptions. It mandates notification to the attorney general regarding hospital mergers/acquisitions of physician practices and physician employment, enhancing oversight of healthcare consolidation. The bill also directs a report on expanding site neutral reimbursement to commercial insurers. These provisions may improve payment equity and access for outpatient palliative care services and influence healthcare delivery models affecting seriously ill patients statewide.
key_provisions: Requires Medicaid to reimburse outpatient hospital services at the same rate as equivalent physician office services, with exceptions for hospital-only technology or evidence-based rationale.
Mandates hospitals to notify the attorney general 90 days prior to mergers or acquisitions of physician group practices or physician-owned practices providing outpatient services.
Requires hospitals to notify the attorney general 90 days before employing or contracting with physicians transitioning from independent practice.
Requires confidentiality and review of merger/acquisition and employment notices by the attorney general, including potential antitrust analysis.
Directs the department of insurance to report to the legislature by November 1, 2026, on the advisability and feasibility of expanding site neutral reimbursement to commercial health insurance.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: While the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, its Medicaid payment parity provision can improve reimbursement for outpatient services commonly used by palliative care teams, potentially enhancing access and sustainability of such care. The oversight of hospital mergers and physician employment may influence healthcare market dynamics, affecting availability and integration of outpatient specialty services including palliative care. The mandated report on expanding site neutral payment to commercial insurers could lead to broader payment reforms benefiting seriously ill patients receiving outpatient palliative care. Overall, the bill indirectly supports financial and structural conditions favorable to outpatient palliative care delivery in Indiana.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care indirectly by addressing payment systems that affect outpatient care settings where palliative care is delivered. It also influences healthcare market consolidation and physician employment patterns, which can alter care coordination and access for seriously ill patients. The site neutral payment report may inform future policies that improve reimbursement equity across payers, benefiting palliative care providers and patients without explicitly naming palliative care.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, hospice care (general or pediatric), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. Its focus on payment parity and healthcare market oversight is relevant and does not fall under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires reporting to the attorney general and mandates confidentiality and review processes, implying regulatory oversight. It also tasks the department of insurance with producing a report on payment policy, indicating regulatory evaluation.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0370
Title: Health care matters.
Description: Health care matters. Requires Medicaid reimbursement for outpatient covered services at a hospital to be at the same reimbursement rate as that provided for the equivalent services at a physician's office. Provides exceptions. Requires specified reporting by hospitals and physicians to the office of the attorney general concerning: (1) a merger or acquisition of a physician group practice; and (2) employment of a physician. Requires the department of insurance to submit a report to the general assembly concerning the advisability and feasibility of expanding site neutral reimbursement to commercial health insurance.

By reducing financial barriers such as travel and lodging costs, the bill indirectly supports seriously ill cancer patients who may also benefit from palliative care services. The program requires collaboration with healthcare providers to notify potential participants and establishes eligibility criteria based on financial need and residency in underserved areas. This initiative enhances access to innovative cancer treatments and may facilitate integration of palliative care within clinical trial settings.

analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care indirectly by addressing financial and logistical barriers faced by seriously ill cancer patients, thereby improving access to healthcare settings where palliative care is often delivered. Bill Number: SB0242
Title: Payment for Medicaid physician services.
Description: Payment for Medicaid physician services. Requires the office of Medicaid policy and planning (office) or a managed care organization to promptly cover physician services rendered in a hospital emergency department by a physician who has entered into a provider agreement with the office or managed care organization, without limiting what constitutes an emergency medical condition. Specifies considerations that must be made in determining whether the prudent layperson standard has been met. Prohibits any delay in or denial of compensation to the physician unless the cause of the delay or denial is specifically provided for in: (1) the Medicaid managed care law; (2) an administrative rule adopted under the Medicaid managed care law; (3) the federal administrative rules on Medicaid managed care; or (4) the provider agreement. Prohibits a managed care organization from denying an emergency services claim solely because the claim code is not listed on the autopay list.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes a statewide stroke plan that includes data collection, quality improvement, and treatment protocols for stroke patients, who often have serious neurological impairments and complex care needs. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, the focus on stroke treatment, follow-up care guidelines, and quality improvement creates opportunities to integrate palliative care services for stroke survivors. The bill impacts healthcare settings and providers caring for seriously ill patients and establishes infrastructure that could support palliative care integration.
analysis.summary: HB1310 requires the Indiana Department of Health to establish and implement a statewide stroke plan, including certification of thrombectomy-capable stroke centers, data reporting, and quality improvement initiatives. The plan mandates hospitals to report stroke treatment data and requires dissemination of evidence-based follow-up care guidelines post-stroke. Although palliative care is not explicitly mentioned, the bill indirectly supports seriously ill stroke patients by promoting coordinated care and quality improvements that could incorporate palliative care services. The impact is statewide, affecting hospitals, emergency services, and stroke patients across Indiana.
key_provisions: Establishes a statewide stroke plan coordinated by the Indiana Department of Health to improve stroke response and treatment quality.
Requires certification and listing of thrombectomy-capable stroke centers and other stroke-certified hospitals.
Mandates stroke data reporting by certified hospitals and emergency medical dispatch agencies to a state-maintained database.
Requires dissemination of evidence-based treatment and community care guidelines for providers managing post-stroke patients after hospital discharge.
Prohibits healthcare facilities from advertising stroke center status without proper certification.
Requires annual reporting of stroke data and recommendations to the governor and legislative services agency.
Encourages data sharing and quality improvement initiatives based on stroke care metrics.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly impacts palliative care by focusing on stroke patients, a population often experiencing serious illness with complex symptom management and rehabilitation needs. The establishment of a statewide stroke data system and quality standards creates opportunities to integrate palliative care into post-acute and follow-up care. Providers caring for stroke survivors may benefit from evidence-based guidelines that could include symptom relief and psychosocial support components. The infrastructure for data collection and quality improvement can facilitate identification of gaps in supportive care, including palliative services, benefiting patients, caregivers, and healthcare teams statewide.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it affects care delivery for seriously ill stroke patients by improving hospital certification standards, data reporting, and follow-up care guidelines. These system-level changes influence healthcare quality and coordination, which are critical for integrating palliative care. The focus on emergency medical services and hospital transfers also impacts care transitions where palliative care can be introduced. The data oversight and quality improvement processes provide a platform to identify and address unmet palliative care needs.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on stroke care certification, data reporting, and quality improvement, which are outside the exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires the adoption of rules concerning stroke triage, transport, and treatment protocols by emergency medical services under existing regulatory frameworks.

Title: Statewide stroke plan.
Description: Statewide stroke plan. Requires the Indiana department of health (state department) to include Indiana hospitals certified as a thrombectomy-capable stroke center in certain lists maintained by the state department concerning certified stroke centers. Amends the list of entities that certify stroke centers. Requires a hospital certified as a thrombectomy-capable stroke center to provide certain information to the state department. Prohibits a health care facility from advertising that the facility is a thrombectomy-capable stroke center unless the facility is certified by a specified entity. Requires the state department to establish and implement a statewide stroke plan. Sets forth requirements of the plan and requirements for certain health care providers to report stroke data. Requires the state department to establish a data base for the reported data and sets forth additional requirements. Requires the state department to annually report certain stroke data to the governor and the executive director of the legislative services agency.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill establishes a Trauma Informed Care Commission focused on identifying best practices and research models for assisting children, youth, and families who have experienced trauma. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, the focus on trauma-informed approaches for vulnerable pediatric populations aligns with upstream pediatric palliative care principles, which address holistic needs beyond medical treatment. The commission’s work on screening, referral, and community interventions creates infrastructure that could support integration of pediatric palliative care services and workforce development.
analysis.summary: HB1241 establishes a temporary Trauma Informed Care Commission tasked with identifying evidence-based best practices and research models to assist children, youth, and families affected by adverse childhood experiences. The commission will submit reports to state agencies and the legislature, aiming to improve trauma prevention and intervention strategies. Although not explicitly about palliative care, the bill indirectly supports pediatric palliative care by promoting trauma-informed approaches that address psychosocial and emotional needs of seriously ill children and families statewide.
key_provisions: Establishes a temporary Trauma Informed Care Commission under the executive branch to operate until June 30, 2028.
Commission tasked with identifying, evaluating, and recommending evidence-based best practices for assisting children, youth, and families who have experienced trauma.
Requires commission to recommend research models for settings where individuals interact with affected children and families, including guidelines for screening, referral, and appropriate responses.

Commission membership includes state health, mental health, family services, education, child services, and criminal justice officials, plus appointed members affiliated with hospitals or organizations serving traumatized youth.
Mandates commission to submit reports with best practices, research models, and trauma prevention strategies to the Secretary of Family and Social Services and the General Assembly.
Encourages study of education-related issues including roles of school counselors and safety planning, which may intersect with trauma-informed care.
Requires public meetings and transparency, with administrative support provided by the office of the Secretary of Family and Social Services.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Indirectly impacts pediatric palliative care by promoting trauma-informed care practices that address psychological, emotional, and social needs of children and youth who may have serious illnesses or complex health conditions. The commission’s work on screening and referral systems can facilitate early identification of trauma-related needs, enabling integration of palliative care services. Inclusion of hospital-affiliated members and focus on community and multigenerational interventions creates opportunities to enhance workforce capacity and quality standards relevant to pediatric palliative care. The statewide scope and mandated reporting support public awareness and policy development that could benefit seriously ill children and their families.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: This bill impacts palliative care through system-level infrastructure that supports trauma-informed approaches, which are critical in comprehensive care for seriously ill pediatric populations. It fosters workforce development by involving diverse stakeholders and encourages quality improvement through evidence-based best practices and research models. The emphasis on screening, referrals, and community interventions benefits healthcare settings where pediatric palliative care is delivered, even though palliative care is not explicitly mentioned.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on trauma-informed care for children and families, which aligns with pediatric palliative care interests and is therefore included.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires the commission to develop evidence-based best practices and research models that include guidelines and procedures for screening and referrals, which may inform future regulatory standards in trauma-informed care settings.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill regulates cost sharing and out-of-pocket expense credits for prescription drugs and health care services under health plans, including those for life-saving drugs and chronic pain management, which are relevant to seriously ill patients who often require palliative care. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it affects payment structures and patient financial protections that can improve access to medications and services critical for symptom management in serious illness. The bill also mandates insurer and administrator compliance reporting and establishes procedures for crediting out-of-pocket payments, indirectly supporting care affordability for patients receiving palliative care.
analysis.summary: HB1604 establishes requirements for insurers, administrators, and pharmacy benefit managers to apply federal cost sharing limits to certain prescription drugs and mandates that health plans credit out-of-pocket payments toward deductibles and out-of-pocket maximums. This improves financial protections for patients managing chronic pain or life-threatening conditions, populations commonly served by palliative care. The bill also requires annual compliance certification and sets procedures for claiming credits, potentially enhancing access to symptom management medications and reducing financial barriers for seriously ill patients statewide.
key_provisions: Requires application of federal annual limitation on cost sharing for prescription drugs that are life-saving or manage chronic pain without approved generics
Prohibits insurers, administrators, and pharmacy benefit managers from conditioning coverage terms based on availability of financial assistance for prescription drugs

Mandates health plans to credit out-of-pocket payments made directly to providers toward deductibles and out-of-pocket maximums if claims are not submitted and payments are below average discounted rates
Requires health plans to establish procedures and documentation requirements for patients to claim out-of-pocket expense credits
Requires annual certification by insurers and administrators to the insurance commissioner verifying compliance with cost sharing requirements
Defines roles and licensing requirements for pharmacy benefit managers and regulates their practices related to prescription drug benefits
Mandates publication or referral to average discounted rates to support patient claims for out-of-pocket credits
analysis.palliative_care_impact: This bill indirectly benefits palliative care patients by reducing financial barriers to accessing essential medications for symptom management, including chronic pain drugs and life-saving treatments often used in palliative care. By limiting cost sharing and crediting out-of-pocket payments toward deductibles, it improves affordability and access for seriously ill patients receiving palliative care services. Insurers and pharmacy benefit managers are held accountable for compliance, potentially enhancing consistent coverage of palliative medications. The statewide application ensures broad impact across healthcare settings where palliative care is delivered.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through changes to health insurance payment structures and patient protections without explicitly mentioning palliative care. It affects reimbursement policies and financial assistance mechanisms that influence access to medications and services critical for symptom relief in serious illness. These systemic changes support healthcare affordability and may improve care continuity for palliative care populations.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. Its focus on cost sharing and insurance regulation is relevant to palliative care through financial protections and medication access.
