analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: HB1604
Title: Cost sharing; out-of-pocket expense credit.
Description: Cost sharing; out-of-pocket expense credit. Requires an insurer, an administrator, and a pharmacy benefit manager to apply the annual limitation on cost sharing set forth in the federal Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act under 42 U.S.C. 18022(c)(1) to prescription drugs that: (1) are covered under a health plan; (2) are life-saving or intended to manage chronic pain; and (3) do not have an approved generic version. Provides that an insurer, an administrator, and a pharmacy benefit manager may not directly or indirectly set, alter, implement, or condition the terms of health insurance coverage based in part or entirely on information about the availability or amount of financial or product assistance available for a prescription drug. Requires, before December 31 of each year, each insurer and administrator to certify to the insurance commissioner that the insurer or administrator has fully and completely complied with the cost sharing requirements during the previous calendar year. Requires a health plan to credit toward a covered individual's deductible and annual maximum out-of-pocket expenses any amount the covered individual pays directly to any health care provider for a medically necessary covered health care service if a claim for the health care service is not submitted to the health plan and the amount paid by the covered individual to the health care provider is less than the average discounted rate for the health care service paid to a health care provider in the health plan's network. Requires a health plan to: (1) establish a procedure by which a covered individual may claim a credit; and (2) identify documentation necessary to support a claim for a credit.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill primarily addresses Medicaid funding mechanisms, including changes to Medicaid payment formulas, hospital assessment fees, and managed care organization assessment fees. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, the changes to Medicaid reimbursement rates and funding structures for hospitals and managed care organizations indirectly affect the financing and delivery of palliative care services to seriously ill patients. The bill also establishes regulatory frameworks and payment programs that could influence access and quality of care for populations served by palliative care.
analysis.summary: HB1586 modifies Medicaid funding in Indiana by adjusting hospital assessment fees, authorizing managed care organization assessment fees, and establishing a state directed payment program to increase Medicaid reimbursement rates for inpatient and outpatient hospital services. These changes indirectly impact palliative care by potentially improving Medicaid payment rates and funding flows to hospitals and managed care organizations that provide care to seriously ill patients. The bill includes provisions for fee formulas, quality measures, and reconciliation processes that could influence service delivery and financial sustainability of palliative care within Medicaid. The scope is statewide, affecting Medicaid beneficiaries and healthcare providers across Indiana.
key_provisions: Extends hospital assessment fee law to June 30, 2027 and modifies fee assessment formulas.
Authorizes a managed care organization assessment fee to fund Medicaid services.
Establishes a state directed payment program to increase Medicaid reimbursement rates for inpatient and outpatient hospital services above Medicare rates.
Requires the hospital assessment fee committee to approve Medicaid state plan amendments and fee formulas related to these payments.
Mandates quality measures to be determined and applied for the state directed payment program.
Includes reconciliation processes to ensure appropriate calculation and distribution of fees and payments.
Requires submission of documentation and approvals from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services for implementation.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly impacts palliative care by altering Medicaid payment structures that fund hospitals and managed care organizations providing care to seriously ill patients, including those receiving palliative care. Increased reimbursement rates and stable funding mechanisms may enhance access to and quality of palliative care services within hospital and managed care settings. The establishment of quality measures and fee formulas creates opportunities to incorporate palliative care-related metrics and incentivize high-quality care. Providers and patients statewide stand to benefit from improved Medicaid financing, which supports the sustainability of services critical to seriously ill populations.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: Though the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, its changes to Medicaid payment formulas, hospital fees, and managed care assessments affect the financial environment in which palliative care is delivered. By increasing Medicaid reimbursement rates and establishing quality measures, the bill indirectly supports care delivery improvements for seriously ill patients. These systemic payment reforms influence provider capacity, access to services, and potential integration of palliative care into broader hospital and managed care programs.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It centers on Medicaid funding and payment policies, which are relevant to palliative care financing without falling under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires submission and approval of Medicaid state plan amendments, waiver requests, and preprints to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, and mandates the hospital assessment fee committee's review and approval of these regulatory documents and payment programs.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill focuses on Medicaid program administration and eligibility verification processes, including modifications to the Healthy Indiana Plan and hospital presumptive eligibility standards. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care or hospice, it affects Medicaid populations, including those with serious medical conditions, by tightening eligibility and enrollment processes. These changes indirectly impact access to Medicaid-covered services, including palliative care, by influencing who qualifies and how hospitals assist patients in obtaining coverage.
analysis.summary: SB0234 establishes stricter Medicaid eligibility verification and reporting requirements, modifies enrollment criteria for the Healthy Indiana Plan, and sets hospital performance standards for presumptive eligibility determinations. These changes affect Medicaid recipients statewide, including individuals with serious medical conditions who may benefit from palliative care services. The bill's provisions on eligibility and hospital responsibilities could influence access to Medicaid-funded palliative care by ensuring accurate enrollment and timely application processing.
key_provisions: Requires the Office of the Secretary of Family and Social Services to annually report Medicaid program data to the Medicaid oversight committee.
Prohibits acceptance of self-attestation for key eligibility criteria including income, residency, age, and household composition in Medicaid enrollment.
Mandates data matching with various state and federal agencies to verify Medicaid recipient eligibility and remove ineligible individuals.
Requires the Office to apply for a Medicaid state plan amendment removing coverage references for a specific adult population under 42 CFR 435.119.
Establishes hospital performance standards and an appeals process related to presumptive Medicaid eligibility determinations.
Modifies eligibility categories and enrollment limitations for the Healthy Indiana Plan, including provisions for individuals with serious medical conditions.
Sets requirements for hospitals to notify the Office of presumptive eligibility determinations and assist applicants with full Medicaid applications.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly address palliative care, it indirectly affects access to Medicaid-funded palliative care services by tightening eligibility verification and enrollment processes. Hospitals are required to meet standards and assist patients in completing Medicaid applications, which can improve timely access to coverage for seriously ill patients needing palliative care. Changes to the Healthy Indiana Plan eligibility, including recognition of individuals caring for dependents with serious medical conditions, may preserve or enhance coverage opportunities for some palliative care populations. The bill also strengthens Medicaid program integrity, potentially impacting funding stability for services including palliative care.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through Medicaid program administration reforms that affect seriously ill patients' access to coverage. By enforcing stricter eligibility verification and hospital presumptive eligibility standards, it influences the healthcare system's ability to enroll and retain patients who may require palliative care. These systemic Medicaid changes create indirect but significant effects on service access and quality for seriously ill populations without explicitly mentioning palliative care.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It addresses Medicaid eligibility and administration, which are relevant to palliative care access and financing without falling under exclusion criteria.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires the Office of the Secretary to establish hospital performance standards and an appeals process for presumptive eligibility determinations, implying regulatory development and enforcement.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0234
Title: Medicaid matters.
Description: Medicaid matters. Requires the office of the secretary of family and social services (office) to report specified Medicaid data to the Medicaid oversight committee. Requires the office to receive and review data from specified federal and state agencies concerning Medicaid recipients to determine whether circumstances have changed that affect Medicaid eligibility for recipients. Prohibits the office from accepting self-attestations of certain information in the administration of the Medicaid program. Requires the office to apply for a Medicaid state plan amendment to remove references to coverage under the Medicaid plan of a certain population. Requires the office to establish: (1) performance standards for hospitals that make presumptive eligibility determinations and sets out action for when hospitals do not comply with the standards; and (2) an appeals procedure for hospitals that dispute the violation determination. Modifies eligibility categories and requirements for the healthy Indiana plan (plan). Specifies limitations for enrollment in the plan.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill addresses pregnancy and childbirth matters including biomarker testing for preeclampsia, establishment of a trauma informed care commission, and programs for pregnant women and children with substance use disorders. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, it impacts seriously ill pregnant women and newborns, a population that may benefit from palliative care services. The trauma informed care commission and substance use disorder program create infrastructure that could integrate palliative care principles and services for affected families. The bill also includes protections and accommodations for pregnancy-related conditions, indirectly supporting health and quality of life for seriously ill pregnant patients.
analysis.summary: SB0521 mandates biomarker testing coverage for preeclampsia, establishes a trauma informed care commission focused on children and youth who have experienced trauma, and requires a program for pregnant women and children with substance use disorders. It prohibits pregnancy-related employment discrimination and mandates reasonable accommodations. These provisions indirectly affect palliative care by supporting seriously ill pregnant women and newborns, creating opportunities for trauma-informed and integrated care approaches statewide.
key_provisions: Requires coverage for biomarker testing for preeclampsia under state employee health plans, Medicaid, and commercial insurance.
Establishes a trauma informed care commission to develop best practices for assisting children, youth, and families experiencing trauma.
Mandates the division of mental health and addiction to develop a program for pregnant women and children with substance use disorders.
Prohibits employment discrimination based on pregnancy or childbirth-related conditions and requires reasonable accommodations.
Requires insurers to provide contraception coverage without out-of-pocket costs for certain women.
Commission tasked with recommending evidence-based trauma informed care models across multiple settings including healthcare and education.
Commission to report strategies to prevent childhood trauma and adverse childhood experiences by July 1, 2027.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly address palliative care, it indirectly supports seriously ill pregnant women and newborns through mandated biomarker testing for preeclampsia, a serious pregnancy complication. The trauma informed care commission promotes best practices that can improve psychosocial support and symptom management for children and families affected by trauma, aligning with palliative care principles. Employment protections and accommodations improve quality of life for pregnant employees with medical conditions. The substance use disorder program for pregnant women and children may facilitate integrated care approaches including palliative support. These provisions benefit patients, healthcare providers, and families statewide by enhancing care quality, access, and workforce capacity in relevant clinical areas.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through healthcare system improvements for pregnant women with serious conditions and their newborns, workforce development via the trauma informed care commission, and quality standards for trauma-informed care models. It expands Medicaid and insurance coverage for biomarker testing, which may facilitate earlier detection and management of serious pregnancy complications. Employment protections and accommodations support patient-centered care and quality of life, key elements in palliative care. These indirect effects create opportunities for palliative care integration without explicitly naming it.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, general adult hospice, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It addresses pregnancy-related health and discrimination issues, trauma-informed care, and biomarker testing, which are relevant to palliative care without falling under exclusion criteria.

analysis.full_bill_text:
Bill Number: SB0521
Title: Pregnancy and childbirth matters.
Description: Pregnancy and childbirth matters. Sets forth requirements for screening for preeclampsia using biomarker testing. Requires coverage for biomarker testing for preeclampsia under a state employee health plan, the Medicaid program, a policy of accident and sickness insurance, and a health maintenance organization contract. Establishes the trauma informed care commission (commission). Requires the division of mental health and addiction to develop and implement a program for pregnant women and children with a substance use disorder. Prohibits an employer from discriminating against an employee who has a condition related to pregnancy or childbirth. Requires an employer to provide reasonable employment accommodations for an employee who has a condition related to pregnancy or childbirth. Requires the civil rights commission to investigate and attempt to resolve complaints relating to pregnancy and childbirth discrimination. Repeals a chapter regarding pregnancy and childbirth accommodation. Requires an insurer that issues a policy of accident and sickness insurance or a health maintenance organization to make available coverage for contraception without out-of-pocket costs to women otherwise covered by health plans sponsored by employers or institutions of higher education that are objecting organizations and do not invoke an optional accommodation under federal law.

bill.title: Medicaid coverage for health related social needs.

extra_metadata.last_action: First reading: referred to Committee on Public Health

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill requires the state Medicaid agency to seek approval for a Section 1115 waiver to cover health related social needs such as housing and nutrition supports. While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, the provision of Medicaid coverage for social determinants of health directly affects seriously ill patients who often face such unmet needs. Addressing social needs can improve quality of life and symptom management, which are core goals of palliative care, thus making this bill relevant to palliative care policy and services.
analysis.summary: HB1360 mandates the Indiana Secretary of Family and Social Services to apply for a Medicaid Section 1115 waiver to provide coverage for health related social needs including housing and nutrition supports. This expansion of Medicaid benefits indirectly supports seriously ill patients by addressing social determinants that impact health outcomes and quality of life. The bill creates opportunities for integrating social needs services with palliative care to enhance comprehensive care for seriously ill populations. The impact is statewide and targets Medicaid enrollees with unmet social needs.
key_provisions: Requires the Indiana Secretary of Family and Social Services to apply for a Section 1115 Medicaid demonstration waiver by October 1, 2025
Waiver application to include coverage for health related social needs such as housing supports and nutrition supports
Defines health related social needs as unmet adverse social conditions contributing to poor health outcomes, including food insecurity, housing instability, unemployment, and lack of transportation
Establishes Medicaid coverage expansion to address social determinants of health for Medicaid enrollees
Effective date of July 1, 2025, for the new statutory provision
analysis.palliative_care_impact: Although the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it indirectly supports seriously ill patients by proposing Medicaid coverage for social determinants of health that commonly affect this population. By addressing housing instability, food insecurity, and other social needs, the bill can improve symptom management, reduce hospitalizations, and enhance overall quality of life—key goals of palliative care. This creates an opportunity for palliative care providers to coordinate with social services and integrate these supports into comprehensive care plans. The statewide Medicaid program and providers stand to benefit from expanded resources to meet complex patient needs.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: This bill impacts palliative care through Medicaid payment reform that includes social needs coverage, which is critical for seriously ill patients often facing these barriers. It influences healthcare financing and quality standards by promoting integration of social determinants into care delivery. The workforce category is relevant as providers may need to coordinate with social service agencies, potentially expanding roles and training. These impacts occur without explicit mention of palliative care but align with its holistic care model.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not focus on aid-in-dying, hospice care (adult or pediatric), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It centers on Medicaid coverage for social needs, which is relevant and appropriate for palliative care policy tracking.

special_flags.regulation_details: Requires the Secretary of Family and Social Services to apply for a federal Section 1115 Medicaid demonstration waiver, which involves regulatory approval and compliance with federal Medicaid rules.

The inclusion of mobile integrated healthcare grants and collaboration on stroke care outcomes creates infrastructure that could support palliative care services within emergency and community settings.
analysis.summary: HB1590 authorizes the use of county local income taxes to fund emergency medical services and allows EMS provider organizations to participate in regional training programs and grant opportunities. It mandates the Indiana EMS commission to include EMSPOs in funding pursuits and authorizes mobile integrated healthcare grants to support innovative care models. These provisions indirectly support seriously ill patients by enhancing EMS workforce capacity, funding, and coordination, which may facilitate integration of palliative care principles in emergency and post-acute care settings statewide.

Bill Number: HB1590
Title: Emergency medical services.
Description: Emergency medical services. Specifies that county local income taxes for emergency medical services may be used to pay costs incurred for the provision of emergency medical services by an emergency medical services provider organization (EMSPO). Provides that an employee of an EMSPO who is engaged in emergency medical services is eligible to participate in training funded by the regional public safety training fund. Specifies that an EMSPO may collaborate in the dissemination of information concerning public and private grant opportunities related to improving outcomes for stroke patients. Requires the Indiana emergency medical services commission (commission) to include EMSPOs when seeking funding opportunities for the support of emergency medical services. Authorizes the commission to award mobile integration health care grants to EMSPOs.

While it does not explicitly mention palliative care, Parkinson's disease patients often require symptom management and supportive care aligned with palliative principles. The registry infrastructure and data collection create opportunities to integrate palliative care services and improve quality of life for this seriously ill population. Therefore, it is relevant due to its indirect impact on palliative care delivery and potential to inform care improvements.
analysis.summary: HB1580 establishes a statewide Parkinson's disease registry managed by Indiana University School of Medicine to collect incidence and treatment data. It requires healthcare providers to notify patients about the registry and report diagnoses, with patient consent for detailed data. This bill indirectly supports palliative care by creating a data infrastructure for a serious illness population that often benefits from symptom relief and supportive services. The registry's advisory committee and data dissemination provisions offer opportunities to enhance care quality and integration of palliative care statewide.
key_provisions: Establishes a Parkinson's disease registry to collect incidence and treatment data statewide.
Requires healthcare providers to notify patients about the registry and obtain consent for detailed data reporting.
Creates an advisory committee including neurologists, patients, public health staff, and researchers to guide registry implementation.
Mandates confidentiality and limits disclosure of registry data to authorized persons with safeguards.
Allows data sharing with other registries, researchers, and public health officials under strict confidentiality agreements.
Provides immunity from liability for persons reporting data to the registry.
Requires notification to medical associations and licensing boards prior to registry implementation.
analysis.palliative_care_impact: The bill indirectly impacts palliative care by focusing on a patient population with a progressive serious illness that commonly requires symptom management and supportive care. The registry infrastructure enables systematic data collection on diagnosis and treatment, which can inform quality standards and care improvements relevant to palliative care providers. The advisory committee structure and data sharing provisions create opportunities to integrate palliative care considerations into clinical practice and research. Patients, providers, and researchers benefit from improved information systems that support coordinated care and potentially enhance access to palliative services in Indiana.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: Though the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it affects the healthcare system for seriously ill patients by establishing a data registry that supports quality measurement and research. The involvement of clinical informatics and population health experts suggests potential for workforce development and improved care coordination. The registry's patient notification and consent processes promote patient-centered care principles aligned with palliative care values. These systemic enhancements can indirectly improve symptom management and supportive care delivery for Parkinson's disease patients.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, hospice care (general or pediatric), medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses on a disease registry for Parkinson's disease, which is relevant to serious illness care and palliative care integration.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires notification to medical licensing boards and associations, implying regulatory oversight and compliance with confidentiality statutes. It establishes data reporting requirements and protections consistent with health information regulations.

analysis.relevance_reasoning: This bill revises the definitions, licensing, and regulatory framework for advanced practice registered nurses (APRNs) in Indiana, including nurse practitioners, clinical nurse specialists, certified nurse midwives, and certified registered nurse anesthetists. APRNs are key providers in delivering palliative care services, particularly nurse practitioners and clinical nurse specialists who often manage symptom relief and care coordination for seriously ill patients. By updating licensing requirements, board composition, and certification standards for APRNs, the bill indirectly impacts the palliative care workforce and the quality of care available to seriously ill patients.
analysis.summary: HB1151 amends Indiana law to add definitions and licensing provisions for various advanced practice registered nurses, including nurse practitioners, clinical nurse specialists, and certified nurse midwives. It expands the Indiana state board of nursing membership and updates certification and renewal processes for APRNs. These changes indirectly support palliative care by strengthening the regulatory framework for APRNs who provide symptom management and care coordination for seriously ill patients. The bill's statewide impact on APRN licensure and regulation may enhance workforce capacity relevant to palliative care delivery.
key_provisions: Adds definitions for nurse practitioner, clinical nurse specialist, and certified nurse midwife as advanced practice registered nurses
Expands Indiana state board of nursing membership from nine to eleven members, including additional APRN representation
Specifies licensing and biennial renewal requirements for advanced practice registered nurses
Amends certification and scope of practice rules for certified nurse midwives and nurse anesthetists
Requires the nursing board to promulgate rules establishing certification equivalency for clinical nurse specialists by December 30, 2026
Allocates renewal fees to support impaired nurses rehabilitation programs administered by the Indiana professional licensing agency
analysis.palliative_care_impact: While the bill does not explicitly mention palliative care, it directly affects the workforce of advanced practice registered nurses who are integral to delivering palliative care services, including symptom management and care coordination for seriously ill patients. By clarifying definitions, licensing, and certification standards for APRNs, the bill supports workforce development and quality standards that can enhance access to specialty palliative care. The expansion of the nursing board and updated regulatory framework may facilitate improved oversight and support for APRNs practicing in palliative care settings across Indiana.
analysis.relevance_beyond_keywords: The bill impacts palliative care through healthcare workforce development by strengthening the regulatory and licensing framework for APRNs, who often serve seriously ill patients in multiple settings. It indirectly influences clinical skill-building by defining roles and certification requirements that ensure APRNs are qualified to provide complex symptom management and care coordination. These systemic changes improve the infrastructure supporting palliative care delivery without explicitly naming it.

exclusion_check.reason: The bill does not address aid-in-dying, general hospice care, medical marijuana, or psilocybin therapies. It focuses solely on advanced practice registered nurse regulation and licensure, which is relevant to palliative care workforce development.

special_flags.regulation_details: The bill requires the Indiana state board of nursing to promulgate rules defining scope of practice and certification equivalency for clinical nurse specialists and certified nurse midwives.

Bill Number: HB1151
Title: Advanced practice registered nurses.
Description: Advanced practice registered nurses. Adds two additional members to the Indiana state board of nursing (board) and changes the required qualifications for certain members. Amends the definition of "certified registered nurse anesthetist". Adds the following definitions: (1) "Certified nurse midwife". (2) "Clinical nurse specialist". (3) "Nurse practitioner". Specifies that a license to practice as an advanced practice registered nurse expires on October 31 in each odd-numbered year. Makes conforming changes.
Status: 1

Sponsors: Cindy Ledbetter, Bradford Barrett, Matt Hostettler
